description:
I came here for lunch since it was free museum day for members of other museums. Since there isn't a lot of options to eat at Golden Gate Park, I had lunch here. They have premade food in the fridge. I skipped those and ordered a quiche and salad. Got a chocolate mousse cake for dessert. Quiche was good. Salad too. Loved the cake. For a cafeteria they bring your food to you and they take away the plates. That's added service. 

Food is ridiculously expensive here but you knew that
author: Wendy H.

description:
Coming to visit golden gate park and grabbing a quick coffee and bite only to encounter the seemingly only rude person in the city we've met so far. 

After ordering food, carrying my tray to the tables outside through one of the only 2 doors. An employee was holding the door open and wiping the glass on the other side. I walked through the door and thanked him with a smile. WHAT I RECIEVED IN RETURN WAS NOTHING BY SPITE AND RUDENESS. The employee stared at me spewing "WHY ARE YOU THANKING ME YOU SHOULD GIVE ME SOME SPACE, IM NOT HOLDING THE DOOR FOR YOU WHATS WRONG WITH YOU" 

Doesn't matter if you are projecting or just having a bad day at 11 am in the morning but that is not excusable. 

All the other staff was fantastic but unfortunately being yelled at for saying thank you to a person holding the door is not what I call a pleasant experience.
author: Morris H.

description: I personally left very happy having there $14 Chardonnay and $12 Sangria sharing Salmon quinoa salad and quiche. Our server were very professional, I felt special. I was surprised by such a service and very healthy/leafy green options.
author: Svetlana K.

description:
This beautiful café is adjacent to the deYoung Musuem. It's a large & beautiful eatery with floor to ceiling windows which allow you to take in all the architectural delights and breathtaking outdoor art. 
I enjoyed drinking a delicious cup of coffee and detectable french macaroons as I took in the luscious greenery that seemed to envelop me. It's a lovely place and a "must visit" when you find yourself in San Francisco!
author: Luisa J.

description: My family and I came here for a quick snack after visiting the de Young museum. My 11 year old sister ordered $9 chicken tenders. What we got was a measly portion of hard, shriveled rocks. Who is managing quality control here? Thankfully they took the food back.
author: Julia C.

description: Please try their special of the day, pretty exceptional. And yes, they are doing tableside service pretty surprising for a museum cafe. Surely will recommend this to my friends to stop by whenever you are around in Golden Gate Park and have a nice lunch after walk because you can enter here for free without buying any tickets to the entrance of the museum.
author: Calvin Nicholei L.

description:
The de Young Cafe is a large, spacious cafe attached to San Francisco's popular de Young fine arts museum inside Golden Gate Park. This is a good place to rest and relax not only when visiting the museum, but also when visiting the park and other attractions nearby. We stopped by the cafe to recharge before heading to the Japanese Tea Garden next door.

The cafe is open in the mornings and afternoons, 9:30am to 4:30pm, Tuesday-Sunday (Monday closed). There's plenty of seating inside and out. The patio is fully covered so it's not cold nor windy. You don't have to enter the museum to access the cafe. The cafe has a separate entrance from the outside via the patio. Restrooms are located inside the museum next to the cafe's museum-side entrance.

When we visited, we stood in line and grabbed a couple drinks from the cafe's grab-and-go selection. Items included bottles of apple juice ($3.25), house-squeezed/pressed OJ and carrot + OJ ($4.50), string cheese ($1), hard boiled eggs ($1.25), Stonyfield organic yogurt ($2), parfaits, white bean and artichoke salad ($5.50), spring orzo salad ($5.50), fruit salad ($5.50), winter farro salad ($5.50), couscous salad ($5.50), mixed baby greens ($8.00), and chicken Caesar salad ($13). They also had specialty sodas like Bruce Cost ginger ale ($3.75), Izze blackberry and grapefruit soda ($3.25), Dry cucumber soda ($3.25), and Stewart's Orange 'n Cream soda ($3.25). The carrot + OJ drink and unfiltered ginger ale (strong flavor) were yummy.

Complimentary water is available self-serve from various dispensers.

The lunch menu contained a variety of light fare like soups, salads, and sandwiches and some hot entrees made in the kitchen.

Good service. There are staff present who bus and clean tables and take away trays.

Along with the museum and tea garden, other attractions that are close by are the California Academy of Sciences, Music Concourse, and Golden Gate Park Segway Tours.
author: Daniel B.

description: Ya so I got a prepackaged salami sandwich.  Will never do that again.  The bread was hard and chewy and the salami tasted old.   Pretty sure it was sitting in the fridge a while.  Messed up my stomach later too.  Of course it's overpriced but what do you expect.  So it was more of the bad quality of the sandwich I'm rating this on.
author: Eric K.

description: It's always a pleasure to grab a quick bite here while browsing the fine art at this wonderful museum. Generally the salads and soups are pretty good when one considers the high volume of people they serve.
author: Caroline V.

description:
Food taste wise, it was pretty...horrible, similar to any other museum cafes that I almost tend to give a zero star; yet service was just...great. So an average of three.

Waitress has come by multiple times to refill my tea, and always asked for if there was anything else that I needed. Really enjoyed my time there even though I disliked my overpriced ahi tuna poke (too heavily dressed with only countable number of tuna chunks).
author: Elaine H.

description:
Avocado toast? Good.

Pastries? Good.

Entrees? Aw, hellll no.

They're sadly overpriced, not flavorful, and nothing to remember really.

I need my mind blown. This spot doesn't do it.
author: Gabriela W.

description:
Zero, zero, zero, zero, zero due to NEGLIGENCE, IRRESPONSIBILITY and STUPIDITY. 

Unfortunately, in order to begin this review I have to place a star. My daughter and I visited the museum on April 6, 2018. We got hungry so we went to the Café. My daughter, being 21 years old, is very diligent about reading all of the ingredients in her food due to the fact that she has allergies to tree nuts. She found a quinoa salad and read all of the ingredients and of course she chose it because it did not list any kind of nuts in the salad. When she opened it and ate it she heard a crunch. My daughter immediately spit up the salad on a napkin. She ran to a person that was working in the café and asked about the salad. She told them that she's allergic to nuts so she requested him to  double check with the kitchen because NUTS were not listed on the list of ingredients that was displayed. The man came back out and said that there was hazelnuts in the quinoa salad that she bought. My daughter was very upset and told them that she had to take her Benadryl immediately or else she will have a reaction. 

As a parent, I was very incensed! I requested to speak to the manager of the café and her name was May Yao. I told her that the café was irresponsible displaying ingredients that were not true to what they had served to the public. I told her that my daughter is highly allergic to nuts and that we will be sitting to watch what her reaction might be to the hazelnuts that she accidentally ate. Also, If she goes to an anaphylactic shock, I will administer her EpiPen but they'd have to call an ambulance and pay for her medical fees due to their negligence. 

Thank goodness my daughter is okay!! However, the café could only say sorry to us and not even reimbursed us for the quinoa salad. It is very upsetting that they did not take this seriously because it could've been a life or death situation. 

Having allergies is no joke and it has to be taken very seriously!
author: E D.

description: The cafe was not a destination but a surprisingly pleasant Sunday Brunch at the museum!!!  Went to the museum early on a Sunday before the crowds, spent a few hours in the museum and then looped back around to the cafe for somethings to eat.  Limited menu and mimosas available, pancakes and the quiche were good. All at an extremely reasonable price, a very nice surprise!!!  After brunch, back to the museum!!!
author: J E.

description:
Fantastic cafe in the midst of a museum. They always fresh ingredients for their dishes (the ones pre-made in the plastic containers are not as good, so select from the freshly made menu).

I have had their soup of the day - always amazing. the flatbread is excellent.

If it's not too cold, definitely sit outside in the sculpture garden - love the space!
author: Rebecca C.

description: The grape and almond gazpacho was so delicious! It had a little kick of cayenne and edible flowers. A work of art to say the least. Staff was very attentive and took care of me by letting me sit down instead of standing in line. They took my order and brought the food to the table. A large room and equally large patio area outside means no waiting for a table! Took the wild roasted salmon Caesar salad back to the hotel for dinner later!
author: Judith C.

description: Food was pretty good, albeit pricey.  For the lines and the cost vs. value I give it just 3 stars.  Service was pretty friendly so all in all say if you are here it will be a decent enough experience
author: Melanie G.

description:
I have eaten many lunches here and they have always been very good.

Last night they had special hours for Bouquets des Art do we had dinner there.

I had the rack of lamb with Romanescu sauce.  It was excellent. Three tiny chops cooked medium rare with nice pink coloring in the center with a small bed of veggies and white beans.

The flavors worked very well together.  I would definitely order it again but a little rich for lunch.

Portions are petite.  I think many men would be unhappy with the portion size, but it was perfect for me
author: Joanna S.

description: Yes, it is expensive but considering the prices of SF in general this is a great place to eat when you are at the museum. Order at the counter and then find a place to sit. I had the risotto and my friend had the gumbo. The gumbo ended up being a great deal because the portion size was large and both tasted really good. I would definitely go back!
author: Sarah S.

description:
No flavor.  Very poor value.  It's like an expensive grammar school lunch room.  If you've eaten at IKEA, it will be familiar.  At least there is salt and pepper at the tables. 

The outdoor seating has a nice view.
author: Javi D.

description:
Loved the ambiance, opened to out of doors art sculptures in nature, coupled with the modernness of the interior.
Food fresh and delicious, served by happy helpful people.
author: Paula S.

description: We had a great lunch at the cafe.  We both had the butter lettuce salad.  One with chicken.   They were very tasty and fresh.  A nice place to take a break from touring the museum.
author: Terry L.

description: We come here on Saturday or Sunday mornings for our coffee fix. This place is not cheap, but for the view from the cafe and the warm atmosphere, I don't mind at all. It's kid friendly and in general this place is just awesome!
author: Ana M.

description: Portions are small, prices atrocious, food is cold and bland. Or maybe they were just having a bad day.
author: Tanvi M.

description: Our dinner is was better than most restaurants in SF. The squash and chestnut ravioli in a fresh mushroom sauce was divine as was the wild caught shrimp in a curry sauce. A real treat!
author: Steven B.

description:
The view is really good and so does the food. But I felt poor treated by the manager that's why I give it just one start. 

My dad came visit me during a work day, so I took him to the museum while I worked here at the cafe. I ordered lunch for me and my data, coffee, snacks, fruit and juice for around $40, sat here from 11am to 1:30pm. Then at 1:30pm, the manager approached me, and asked me to leave. She said I sat there from 9:30 and their policy require me to either order another lunch or leave.

I was busy replying to my boss's email, so I was not in the mood arguing or paying attention to her, so I just left and found a place outside continuing to reply to boss. When I finished work, I remember what she said to me and felt deeply discriminated. The manager does not ask me nicely, she gave me that 'you does not belong here' look, saying everyone saw me since 9:30am, which is not true because I was still in the meeting at my office back then. 

I would never come back again after this experience.
author: Ya W.

description: Great place to take a break while exploring Golden Gate Park.  The menu is always surprising and food is delicious.  Staff is friendly and helpful. Beer, wine and cocktails in the Park!
author: Joe K.

description:
Excellent for what it is, a convenient location for a break in the day or place to meet.

What I enjoyed about the place:

The entire house is conscience of service

The selections offer both cold and warm menu item; fresh vegetables in sandwiches and wraps. Everything was good and healthy; absent of heavy sauces instead relies on the taste of fresh ingredients.

Offers sparkling wine and a wide variety of beverage selections, the chai tea was nice too.

The operations is prepared for large groups and busy times and has a waiting line expeditor as well as servers to bring orders to tables.

Good value.

Clean surrounding

Did I mention offers splits (375ml) of sparkling wine?

Try this place, you'll enjoy the staff as all were very pleasant and added to the over all experience.  Thank you, I had a nice day and I'll visit again. 

Overall...excellent job de Young Cafe!
author: Miss T.

description:
Probably the best museum cafe I've been to.  

The staff was very friendly and helpful.  They will try to find a seat for you and even offer to get you water.
author: Keith S.

description:
Generally speaking, museum food is left for the desperate and starving. A last resort when stuck in a wasteland of little options. de Young Cafe, however, would stand up to most casual dining options in San Francisco, museum food or not. 

How often does an institutional cafe offer daily specials with fresh ingredients? Or actual plates/silverware? Not to mention the servers who bring your food out to you when it's prepared fresh. There's no sneeze guard or stale bread allowed! One can even enjoy a glass of wine with their meal, which is oftentimes necessary when you're entertaining out of town guests ;)

Have dined here several times over the years and am always pleasantly surprised about the quality of food and service. Salads are always a safe bet if you're having lunch, you won't be disappointed with wilted greens or waxy fruit. Yesterday's SOD was tomato bisque, which was nice, hot, and creamy. And it came with bread 'n' butter. 

If given the choice of eating at de Young or having a hot dog in GG park, pick de Young cafe next time. You'll be pleasantly surprised!
author: Abby S.

description:
Expensive, definitely, for what you get. My mom and I shared a tuna salad, two pastries, a cappuccino and an espresso and it was about $35. 

However, everything was pretty delicious. The tuna salad felt fresh and delicious, chocolate flourless cake was rich (split with someone!) and chocolate mousse tart (which we got a to go box for because of how rich the flourless cake was) was even better the day after.

Get there before noon! We went Thursday at 11:30, and it was pretty empty. But by the time we left, around noon, it was PACKED.
author: Amanda H.

description:
We had toured only part of the de Young museum and were hungry so decided to eat at the Cafe.  It was a bit confusing, so here's the set-up:  As you enter you are handed a menu of the items you can order, BUT they also have a large selection of "grab and go" items.  The menu items that are prepared to order and delivered to your table range from starters, salads, pizzas and entrees such as roast chicken.  The starters started at $8.  Other items on the menu went up from there.  We went with the Grab and Go. They had a number of prepared salads, sandwiches, wraps, fruits, and desserts.  There are four registers, two to the right and two to the left.  You go to the register to order from the menu, order hot beverages, AND to pay for Grab and Go.  My Grab and Go orzo salad had peas, pine nuts, bell pepper, mint and other things in a light vinaigrette dressing, it was tasty with a bit of kick from something.  My brother-in-law had the quinoa salad with cranberries and other goodies.  Each of these salads (and others) came in a plastic container holding about two cups and cost $5.50.  BIL also had a tuna nicoise salad.  It came in a larger container as it contained a lot of greens and a scoop of tuna salad along with olives and cost a bit more.  My husband had a chicken cobb wrap at $9.50.  It was substantial but he did not like it too much.  We watched as people received their ordered foods and they were presented in nice plates, artfully arranged.

There was plenty of seating when we were there on a Sunday at lunch time.  Tables are bussed quickly.  There are plastic cups and iced water for free.
author: Jacquelin S.

description: The two stars are for the very good food, but the staff (mostly the manager, walking around and yelling that there were multiple lines to pay) really makes the experience disappointing, considering the prices!
author: Manny H.

description: I took my parents to the DeYoung Museum to see the Summer of Love experience. After we stopped by the DeYoung Café. It was slammed on a Sunday afternoon. There were 6 of us so we were sure we'd never find a table. The manager, Chris, quickly responded by arranging tables and locating lots of chairs to accommodate us! I was so relieved because my parents are not easy to please. They loved the food  (tuna tar tar salad AMAZING) and I couldn't have asked for a better experience !! Thank you Chris and Staff.
author: Rachel G.

description: Very good selection with many fresh fruit and vegetable items.  Location was great.  Stopped for a break and lunch.  Lots of seating inside and out.  Service quick and friendly. Salads large and fresh.  Fresh fruit salad was very good.  Split a sandwich which was plenty to share.  Would gladly eat here again.
author: Judy B.

description:
I've only head good things
But great spot 
The food is excellent here!
What a treat
Decadent flourless chocolate cake and tea plus an amazing corn bisque and 
Scallop dish that had great presentation
author: Jenny P.

description:
Many museums around the world have good food at quite reasonable prices. The de Young cafe has both pre-made food such as sandwiches and salads, and made to order foods. The ingredients are fresh and the quality is good. There is plenty of friendly, professional staff in the attractive (but noisy) dining room. 

However two issues reduce the rating from 5 to 3 stars. The prices are a bit high. OK, this is SF and food prices are high at many establishments. But $13.00 for tuna salad in a plastic take-out container is even higher than Financial District prices. Add chips and a drink and my tab was $22. 

Secondly, the process for ordering and paying for food is stressful and takes way too long. I stood in line for 15 -20 minutes, then reached a confusing central intersection of lines heading to four cashiers. This doesn't work for older people or parents with children. There is no alternate process if all you want is a cup of coffee or something else minor and quick. Hopefully cafe management will figure out some improvements.
author: LH M.

description:
Wonderful outdoor seating area!  A lot of San Francisco outdoor dining is on the sidewalk or a sectioned off area in the street.  You see cars and breathe in their fumes.  But the de Young Cafe is mostly enclosed in a large area with a view of their sculptures on a medium-sized lawn.  You can find seats both in the shade and in the sun, and there is also an indoor dining area.  

Food is pretty good, especially for a museum; it's actually quote comparable to other cafes.  

I would definitely meet a friend for lunch here because of the good food and lovely ambiance.
author: Jaching H.

description:
Visiting San Francisco for museums and food.  7 reviewable meals and this was, by far, the worst.
And, for one major reason:  bland.  Did they even use salt?  Soup and tuna wrap.  
So, if you're on a seasoning restricted diet, maybe 4 or 5 stars.
But, I'm all about flavor and there really was none.  Even the mayo in the wrap was strangely lacking.  
I'll allow that I only have 2 data points here, but that's what I had and this was my reaction.
I'll also note that if San Francisco wasn't one of America's top food cities, the contrast might not have been as great and I might have given 2 stars.

I'll also add that I overheard a woman speak directly to the chef, inquiring about the types of oils used in a grain salad.  She ended by saying "I'm glad I asked and your signage should include that information!"  Guessing some peanut oil and she (or someone in her party) was allergic.  The chef's reaction was also telling:  I would have expected abject apologies, but his body language was reserved and polite - as if this wasn't really a concern.  

The cafe at the Legion of Honor was quite good and the cafe at the Asian, where I had the pork dish modeled on the port sculpture in the Emperor's Treasure exhibition was very good.
author: Michael W.

description: For such a calm, lovely spot, this cafe was chaos. Confusing line ups and ordering systems. When I was finally able to order, I asked for the seafood stew. The gentleman who rang in my order gave me a knife and fork for my soup. I asked for a spoon for my meal. He kind of sneered and said it's a pretty hearty stew but obliged and gave me a spoon. Turns out my stew definitely needed a spoon. Apart from the seafood itself in the stew, which was lovely, the dish wasn't great...and not that hearty. Bland, canned tomatoes with really salty garlic croutons that had an aioli blob on each one would mix with the broth in odd chunks. It was like some concoction my mother would freeze in order to get rid of excess celery in her fridge. It was all just very weird.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Great place for a quick meal. Mostly recommend the grab to go items, they are delicious, made with healthy ingredients and a good value for SF. I would steer away from the menu, the entrees are small and the taste bland but healthy too. Good selection of wines, I like they carry many half bottles. 

The outdoor seating is awesome.
author: AF G.

description:
After wandering around the vast collections at the de Young, you are bound to be pretty hungry. 

This cafe is located on the main floor on the opposite side of ticket purchases not too far from the gift shop. They've got their menu displayed at the front but if you don't see anything appealing on it, don't be deterred. They also carry various sandwiches, salads, and snacks in cases by the cashiers.

I didn't really see much on the menu I'd want to eat. It all seemed a little fancy for my tastes. Lamb shank? No thanks, how about a burger and fries please? But unfortunately this place caters more to the former and it is all pretty pricey. They did offer a soup of the day with a multigrain roll for only $7.50 so I opted for that and some free ice cold water they offered.

Soup of the day, the tomato bisque, was pretty tasty and I was glad for the roll to dip in, but I was left a tad hungry.

They've got indoor and outdoor seating so you won't be left standing somewhere. I'd suggest enjoying the views outside as they've got some fun sculptures displayed.

If you're into the kind of expensive food they serve here, go for it. But if you're like me, go to one of the food trucks behind the Music Concourse that seem to always be there or next door to the Japanese Tea Garden. They also serve some food but at much less scary prices.
author: Emily G.

description: I would recommend coming here for lunch or espresso drinks  if you are in the de Young.  We had the pasta salad, soup, kids meal, flourless chocolate cake and all were terrific.  You can eat in the sculpture garden or inside.  Price good for the quality of the food and atmosphere.  We did not get the capuccinos (sp?) but they looked good!
author: Trevor P.

description:
We were blessed with such a beautiful day in the city during our visit. The sun was shining brightly and laid out a bit of heat with a nice breeze. We wanted a quick snack before our exhibit so we wandered in for a bite.

What I swallowed:

BERRY ALMOND TART: The crust on this was crisp and perfectly buttered. The almond paste was delicate and sweet against the perfectly glazed and tarty berries. It was delicious! 

I was very happy with my snack choice while sipping ice cold lemon water on the patio. It's a bit pricey here at the museum but that was a bit expected. The sun was coming overhead but the building provided half shade, half sun and the breeze was just perfect outside. There's a huge blue open safety pin piece of art and other statue-berry-lookin' pieces to admire while you soak up the beautiful day chatting with your friends.
author: Vivian A.

description:
(Long overdue review):  We ate lunch there on September 14 and it was a very positive experience.  It's cafeteria style, but a very friendly young man brought us utensils and water.  Afterwards I complimented the manager and he was also very friendly.  My husband had the pasta special - which was tortellini ($13) - and I had the gnocchi ($12).  The food was *delicious* and attractively presented.

The café is large and looks out on the grounds.  It was noisy, but that's to be expected.
author: Susan L.

description:
We stopped here in the middle of our walk through of the museum.  I was shocked how expensive the food was for what you actually get.  I would have liked the flatbread we ordered to be hotter, the soup to be larger and dessert pie to have better filling to crust ratio.  In the end, nothing impressed me and I felt like I was in an overpriced cafeteria.  

The restaurant was kept really cold (felt like 67ish) which one person I was with liked.  I did like the lemon water they had sitting out. Overall this was a terrible value and forgettable food experience. Since the menu changes regularly many of the recommended dishes I read about were not available.  I would not come here again and do not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Seth R.

description:
The shepherd's pie was delicious and the servers helpful, but good Lord, at what cost?

$14, apparently. Yep. That's how much a bowl of shepherd's pie cost... It was a great meal, and I have no complaints about the wait time (4 minutes), but $14 is a steep price for some mashed potatoes and groundbeef stew*.

Look, I get it. This is a café in an art museum; the prices rival those of movie theaters and airports. But I'm a stingy, bitter person who loves to whine, so I don't care.

I also bought a small thing of yogurt, and my dad got a cold cut turkey sandwich, a can of San Pellegrino, and a banana. Guess what the total was.

$32, plus tip.

My miser's heart has shrunk another inch in volume. 

(Also, bring a coat! It gets chilly.)

*Yep, their dish was more of a soupy stew than a classic shepherd's pie. I'm not complaining, though. It tasted great.
author: Connie C.

description: Beware - "kitchen closes at 4pm" which is not posted or communicated anywhere. If you need food between 4pm-4:30, steer clear.
author: Robert A.

description: The garden with sculpture is pretty cute. We boyfriend ordered a half chicken with spagetti. The food is okay but the plate is really artistic.
author: Hayley H.

description: The napkins are towels. The outdoor seating is the best. Feels good to be outside after walking around from room to room. My friend got the cinnamon bun. It was delicious! Everything is a little pricey. But that's supply and demand!
author: Nika L.

description:
Arriving for the show of art works from Scotland, we chose to fortify ourselves first with a good lunch.  I generally eat salads, but it was a foggish, windy day, and the bouillabaise tempted me.  At $14.00, the hot meal was a much better deal than the shrimp salad of the same price, and the aroma was exquisite.  I also opted for a petite bottle of Proseco, to round out the soup.  My beau got pork belly with the most delicious cheesey polenta I have ever tasted!!  All in all, surprisingly substantial food for a museum cafe!  All the helpers, servers were friendly, which helped because for some reason the whole process is confusing there (double line?, cafeteria? take-out?---who knew?)  I loved the food, the process could use a bit of a redesign.  
Dining outside, under a cantilevered overhang and watching the fog, the sculpture garden, and the Palace of the Legion of  Honor across the way, made for a memorable visual and gastronomic experience.
author: Saralee S.

description:
I didn't realize how much I enjoyed this restaurant until I found it closed on a Monday and had to make a second choice for lunch that fell very short of the de Young.

Daily specials that are freshly prepared are always popular.  The menu is not big by any means, but all of the food is prepared with care and presents well on the plate, plus the variety of options are substantial enough to satisfy most diners.  Comparing this dining experience with more upscale casual dining in nearby downtown San Francisco makes this cafe a bargain.  The restaurant uses a lot of local grown organic fruits, meats, and vegetables and everything tastes very fresh. I've had quick lunches here on several occasions since the museum opened a few years ago and I have never been disappointed. You don't have to be a museum visitor to enjoy the de Young Café. The location offers nice views of the gardens and museum across the concourse from the de Young Museum.

Great service, good food, nice atmosphere.  A pleasant cafe to take a break and enjoy a flavorful meal on your visit to Golden Gate Park.
author: Walt N.

description:
Got food poisoning from their boxed salad. Whoever is supplying them will be investigated.   My friend who ate a little of what I had also got sick, we got proportionally sick to the amount we consumed.

We ate lunch on Fri Jan 20, by Sat early morning was painfully sick.  Had to go to the ER to rehydrate by Sat night. 
  
Thanks for ruining half of my vacation, racking up out-of-network medical bills, and disappointing family and friends who I only see once a year.

Good news?  I am healthy and could combat the poison.  The demographic of the de Young clientele is not so young and not necessarily so healthy.  The Cafe better get a handle on how they are sourcing and dating their food.  There were NO dates on the packaging.
author: Ellen C.

description:
25-November, Sunday
My post-exhibition ritual whenever I have just traversed through the De Young Museum is to wind down and lounge beneath the cantilevered roof in the outside environment with the warmth of a savory Mocha in-hand.  It is very relaxing to watch the little kids running around the natural surroundings of the lush garden grounds and the Golden Gate Park, the lightly audible overlap of the surrounding conversations in many different tongues.  

The Herzog & de Meuron structure always feels very permeable, open, inviting and overall impactful to me. Although, I do have mixed feelings about the inside café because it feels like an odd version of an assembly line cafeteria straight out of high-school which is why I prefer to always sit outside especially on a sunny day when the sun is slightly angled overhead and the light is dramatically filtered through the textured perforations of the copper façade that has this really beautiful patina to it.
author: Ty T.

description: Don't order the bruschetta, it's absolutely disgusting! They serve you two pieces of dried out bread, with a dab of some kind of white sauce, and then a large piece of stinky raw salmon. I was so grossed out by the smell and appearance, I didn't even taste it. However, my boyfriend did try it and said it was the worst bruschetta he's EVER tasted! Completely killed our appetites. We will not return. It's worth the extra effort to just go somewhere outside of the museum to eat, and I'm sure they'd have better prices.
author: Sarah G.

description:
VERDICT: Nice servers, with a good small, quick selection to quench that thirst or settle that hunger. EXCEPTIONAL SERVICE

QUALIFIER: After a long walk in the park or museums, our group was tired

FOOD: Just ok for cafe foods

SERVICE: Toward the end of the day, the staff was closing the kitchen, so my friend ordered a desert tart. After taking two bites, the cashier came back to our table and replaced our tart with an entirely freshly prepared tart!
author: Harry T.

description:
We always get great food at the cafe.  If you stray away from the regular menu & try a special expect a pleasant surprise.  

Yesterday, in honor of the Dutch exhibit Girl with a Pearl Earring, the menu featured some traditional Dutch fare.  We had the veal croquettes with mustard and cornichons, which were heavenly.  More of an appetizer size, could have had two plates easily.  

We also tried the Stamppot, which is a traditional Dutch dish made from a combination of potatoes mashed with kale, lardons (which were UNDERDONE, chewy bacon...ewww) and two sausages accompanied by the same great mustard on the side. Overall Delish! 

Next time you're at the museum try the cafe and explore the specials or new additions.  Once they even had short ribs that took a while to come out of the kitchen but were worth the wait.  Never fails to satisfy, plus the staff is super friendly and helpful.
author: B K.

description:
We stopped here for a bite on our trip to De Young. We didn't expect much. But it was super. We were greeted by a super friendly man who showed us how the cafe worked. He directed us to areas for a quick pick up or a full on meal. The food was GREAT. 
Shrimp skewers with organic greens, Flat bread with fresh cheese, cherry tomatoes and chunks of sausage. Everything we ordered was just better than we hoped. 
We had just done a week in SF with trips to some really high end restaurants. This place was just as good as many. Outstanding job Folks! Highly recommend.
author: Steve M.

description:
Hidden in the back of the De Young - I didn't even know it existed the first time I came. Huge selection of pastries, which is really nice. Also, it's awesome that you don't have to pay admission to go into the cafe (unlike the one at the Academy of Science) so you can just go in for a nice rest after walking around Golden Gate Park.

Typical cafe prices, so it's not like they're over-charging you for coffee (as it's usually pricey anyways). I tried the fruit tart and the scone. Scone was a little bland, fruit tart was not too shabby. The fruit tart was more of a whipped cream than custard. 

Will def. come back for when I need to take a break from all that walking! Also, I'd love to try the rest of their huge selection of pastries....those bars looked super good.
author: Jennie C.

description:
Three stars might be pushing it, because every time I've been here it feels like a pretentious cafeteria. 

The food is so-so. I've had lots of snack odds and ends, but most are prepackaged foodstuffs. I did recently have their chocolate dipped Madelines which were fresh and tasty, surprisingly.  However, their bag of chips cost me $3.50 and they were stale. I spent over $11 for three items, non of which were hot or more than a snack item (chips, bottled beverage and cookies). Their salads alone are $12+. The woman in front of me ended up spending almost $70 for a few people to have LUNCH. The desserts looked tasty, but were priced as much as an upscale bakery. 

Also, the queue set up here is atrocious. The museum itself is usually pretty busy, and it can get rather stuffy, but it's even worse in the cafe. I felt like I was being herded to the cash register. Not only that, most people were incredibly rude/pushy or just plain old jerkface dummy-heads. The snobby women in front of me who took 20 minutes to pick out the wine they wanted with their meal really irked me. 

There is ample seating inside and out with table service after ordering. On a nice day, it's a treat to sit outside and enjoy a bite. However, be very aware that a "snack" will probably set you back more than you expect.
author: Bianca U.

description:
Love the museum, but I feel that the cafe is pretty low quality food. 
I just tried the lamb plate it was pretty bad. I wasn't happy about it.
author: Daniel D.

description:
The food was excellent. The coffee was not bad but not outstanding for San Francisco- weak espresso. 

However, the service was what irritated me. This was, of course, not a cheap place to eat. That's fine. However, when the swordfish lunch plate costs $16 and the coffee costs $3.50, I expect table service, and not to have to stand on line as if it is a cheap cafeteria.
author: Daphne X.

description: I popped in for a quick lunch while visiting the museum.  To keep it simple I headed to the grab-and-go section and got a veggie  wrap, some German potato salad, a fresh peach and a small bottle of apple juice. The food was okay, not great, but would have been a decent deal for  $13 or $14. Unfortunately, this simple, mediocre little meal set me back $22.50!!! Sorry, but this is just effing ridiculous. There are lots of good and reasonably priced eateries within a 15 minute walk or a 5 minute bus ride of the DeYoung. Do yourself a favor and patronize one of them instead of this ripoff.
author: Bruce M.

description:
I always hesitate when it comes to eating at cafes connected to any building.  Whether talking about the food court in ikea, airport food stands & cafes, or zoos and amusement parks.  I feel like they get away with serving mediocre food at high prices.

  But I arrived early to my appointment to check out the Picasso exhibit, and was hungry.  And a hungry Mike looking at art that probably won't excite him too much could get ugly..  I knew a full Mike would look at this art with a little better view, a more charitable light.

I saw all the good looking entrees being served to the other customers. But I didn't want anything fancy, so I walked to the counter and saw the ready-made baguettes.  Good enough, I thought to myself.  The baguette and a diet coke was $13.00.

Most of the time my problem with ready-made baguettes is that they are dry.  No mayo, no tasty lubrication between the bread, meat, and cheese.  But to my surprise de Young Cafe's baguette has a nice pepperoncini type relish that made it moist and went well with the quality salami, Mortadella, and provolone cheese filled hoagie of love.

I have to say it was a great start to my evening which was sure to see my A.D.D kick in at any moment.  Next review is the museum itself, to be continued...
author: Michael L.

description:
Pluses for the atmosphere, cleanliness, and friendliness of the staff who were probably taking care of customers at a 15:1 ratio - kudos to you all for still being able smile and keep cool.

Minus star for the price!! And the ok-ness of the food relative to that price. One sandwich and an americano was $12.something. And the sandwich wasn't even that big or good. And that thing cost $9.50. meh.
author: Sarah K.

description: For one of the only places to offer food in the immediate area, it's pretty good. Selection of food will satisfy most, seating is plentiful and even faintly picturesque if you opt for a window or outdoor spot. Due to the monopoly of eateries in the park, it's naturally overpriced for what you get- which is likely my only gripe for this place.
author: Nikko A.

description:
This place is very confusing. The food tastes horrible. My friends mom and her cousin and me went to the museum. We got hungry so we saw a cafe and we went in. There was only three choices on the kids menu. ARE YOU KIDDING ME? 

This place is very expensive. it's a rip off. You get terrible food that is very expensive

NEVER GO TO THIS PLACE
author: Bella P.

description: I feel like I have to give this place props.  For some reason, I've been to the De Young cafe each time I've gone to the museum.  Yet, I always have a pleasant experience.  They have a nice mix of beverages and food that can cover the just slightly peckish to downright hungry.  Plus they keep the space very clean and the staff are always super friendly.  Great place to start or end a date.
author: Seth E.

description:
Food is alright but expensive.

So I went to the museum to see the impressionism exhibit but decided to purchase some food first. The high prices weren't that surprising. So, I decided to buy a to-go sandwich (ham, arugula, tomato aoli and brie on brioche) and some kettle chips. It sounded so good. But after actually eating it, I can truthfully say that I would have been just as happy with a ham and swiss on wonder bread that could make at home. In fact, I would have been happier since this sandwich was unbelievably bland. 

I live the atmosphere as it feels very modern. The tables are clean and the chairs are light so you won't have too much trouble setting up a table if you have a large group. 

In short: the pre-made stuff was bland and overpriced like the rest of the menu, atmosphere is ok, the service is whatever. I may be back but I don't really want to. Sure, I may go back to the museum itself, but if I'm hungry I'll just find someplace in the city. There are so many places in SF to go eat that I have no problem overlooking this place. 

My recommendation: eat here if you must while enjoying the museum, but one trip is enough, even if this cafe is gourmet.
author: John B.

description:
Yea, it's expensive and overpriced, but I will say we had good service (despite it not being a waited cafe) and the food was all fresh and tasty.
Plus, we had ordered a mushroom soup to share and when we asked for extra bowls, she came back with two extra bowls OF SOUP for each of us instead. Maybe it's just because we had a cute baby with us, but either way, definitely made us feel a tad pampered and actually made the soup much more worth it. Instead of one bowl for 7$, we got a bowl and 2 smaller cups!
author: Adrienne L.

description:
The de Young Cafe is a great place to have lunch when you're visiting the museum. The food is tasty and, if the weather is good, the outside seating is fabulous.

For those dragging young children through the museum, the cafe offers an expanse of lawn which is perfect for kids to "let off a little steam" during a visit to the museum. Plan your trip with kids so that half of the museum exploration is before lunch and the second half after lunch. The kids will thank you and you won't go nuts trying to keep them calm. Perfect!
author: Diane M.

description:
Took my Turkish mother-in-law here before touring the museum.  We were there at 3:30pm, so not busy at all.  The food came out very quickly (less than 5 mins.)  Mom ordered a salmon salad ($14) and unfortunately the salmon, in her opinion was not super fresh.  I might have eaten it but she is very particular.  

Now, here is where the 5 stars come in; As I got up from the table to bring the dish back to the register the very kind and helpful bus boy stopped me and said he would return it and bring us a menu to order something else.  Only a moment later did the manager arrive with the menu and an apology.  Mom ended up ordering what I had, the mushroom and butternut squash quiche (super yummy! - $12)  That came out in less than 2 minutes.  The manager revisited us stating the $2 price difference (in our favor) and asked if he could bring us coffee and/or dessert or refund the $2.  We opted for the dessert of chocolate molten cake.  Wowza, that cake, Man!

Anyway, the service we received so far exceeded what I would expect from a self-serve cafe.  The food was superb and management top-notch.

I read some reviews about prices being too high.  I found the prices to be very reasonable for what we got.  Under the Yelp price range guide our lunch bill was considered on the low end of moderate ($11-30 per person.)  The atmosphere is fantastic, food is delightful and service impeccable.
author: Patricia R.

description: This is my goto brunch spot. Also my favorite place to bring out-of-towners for longer meetings - they always love it. Skip the boxed food and go for the kitchen cuisine. It's usually great, with local ingredients.   It's the outdoor seating though that makes this place spectacular, dropped right in the heart of a sculpture garden with miro and calder.
author: Alex M.

description:
This place is growing on me.

Mother's Day Sunday @ 2:30 pm was PERFECT. 

For the prices paid for the food, we were extremely satisfied. It was sunny and we sat outside on their enclosed balcony and we were under no obligation to go into the museum. Just enter through the outside entrance and let them check your bags if you have any. Yay for terrorism fears. 

We split everything. 
Took place during the Dutch art display of May.

Grolsch: Lrg Dutch Beer ($7) - light, but full of body and perfect on a hot day or with fried food. Recommend. Also, this has a cool clamped closure. 

Bitteballen or Dutch Veal Croquettes  ($7) - so nice, I ordered them twice. Comes with super spicy mustard (I say that loving spicy mustard) and gherkin pickles. I got five nice sized balls which were a nice large portion if you're buy yourself or perfect to split. A smooth mix of minced meat and seasoning with a breading and deep fried.

Stampot ($9) - small mound of creamy potatoes mixed with a little kale, crispy thick bacon cooked just right and added just the right note of smoke & pork, plus one sausage (which was spicy). I would've liked a little more food on the plate, but my mother was satisfied despite her low tolerance for spice (which the sausage had come with a warning). 

BBQ Quail w/ Green Papaya Noodle Salad ($11) - holy smokes was this good and it came with TWO quails which made it perfect for sharing, especially since Mom needed a break from her spicy sausage. Succulent. Sweet. Cooked exactly as it should be and packed with flavor. The noodle salad was a perfectly nice combination of subtle sweet & sour flavors, adding zest and filling, while still being light. I was also craving quail like crazy, so a double good score!

I also ensured that I gave my gratitude to the cooking staff before leaving.

Waiters were polite and helpful. They have been each time I've attended as well.
author: Ziggy J.

description: I appreciate the quality of service and good food. There is always something different on the menu or you can opt for a sandwich. This is always my standby when I visit the museum.
author: Janice O.

description:
This café is quite big and handy for a quick lunch after walking for a couple of hours throughout the park. 

The pastrami sandwich was filling and good. The ice creams only contain natural ingredients and do taste like pistachio

Before leaving the museum, don't forget to take the elevator to the last floor, it is free and you'll get great views over the city, provided that the fog is not too strong. 

Once you walk out of the café, if you turn left and keep walking along the bridge on weekends, you might run into those really fun and free outdoor swing dance classes.
author: Laetitia L.

description: Museum cafes are rarely fulfilling and usually over priced. Ok so it suffers from the latter sometimes but the selection is great. Staff are generally good even when it's crowded. However as of late there are a number of food vendors that have popped up around the grounds and obviously the Moss Room is just across the way. However, if you just cant leave the vicinity, this cafe is better than your average captive audience venue
author: Kim N.

description:
As far as museum cafes go - the De Young Cafe is on point. Their selection of food is impressive. From filling reubens, to dreamy sounding ravioli, to fresh salads, and to divine looking desserts. While the lines here can get busy during peak times, the staff are efficient and personable and make sure that the line to order  -  moves smoothly.

I ended up only getting a jasmine green tea here. I was excited to see that it was Mighty Leaf - one of my favorites. Sipping on hot herbs - while looking out at onto De Young's picturesque courtyard - before the New Year - was a much needed mellow start to what I am sure is going to be one crazy night.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Definitely a little overpriced but a really cute cafe in Golden Gate Park! My family was getting a little cold walking around the park so we decided to stop in for a coffee. My parents ordered a hot chocolate, which was perfect in syrup and heat and my sister had a mocha which was good according to her as well. I had a regular coffee which was nothing special but I liked the cute little mug they gave it to me in and I also liked how much seating was available at the restaurant. Finally we ordered a lemon tart, which was a little expensive for how tiny it was, but SO TASTY! Such a good pairing with our drinks. 

There was a lot of food on the menu too that we did not try since we had lunch just a couple hours ago, but it seemed like there was a huge variety! Good place to stop in between your walks or to grab a cup of coffee inside after walking around.
author: Anu P.

description: Stopped in for a light snack, customer service and staff was great. Nice place to chill and have coffee or lunch, and it's convenient to Japanese Tea Garden, and Museums.
author: Mika D.

description:
We were totally surprised by the food at De Young Museum Cafe 

High priced? Yes.... 

But delicious? Yes! 

Hungry after battling the crowds at the Impressionists exhibit, heavy sighs abounded at the thought of eating at the Museum restaurant but w/ little-to-no alternative choices, we decide to enter 

All I can say is WOW 

Artichoke & Apple Bisque - strong flavor of artichoke & just a hint of sweetness from the apple.....great combination 

Artichoke, Mushroom & Truffle Quiche - extremely savory & strong truffle taste which is a high compliment 

Cog Au Vin - chicken was tender & sauced just right (so my friend said) 

Mac N Cheese was the only downer - but it was on the kids' menu so I expect they had catered it towards finicky kids cause it was bland.  Twisty pasta cooked almost al dente was good & there seemed to be a good bit of cheese - there were distinct pulls but it was just bland.  Again, chalked it up to the fact it was a kid's item so no garlic or truffle which would have been incredibly good.....alas

Lots of tables to accommodate the masses & there's even a covered outside area for those who wish to enjoy more of a garden-type feel

We'd totally come back & plan to do just that after the next Impressionist exhibit
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Had a nice lunch today, elegant food but small portions; I'm sure that is why society ladies are so thin.  Had a crab cake which was a nice mid-afternoon snack, with coffee for $21.00 including tip.

I take away a star because I don't understand why they want to bus the tables while people are still sitting there.  I've eaten there numerous times over the years and someone always interrupts to ask if they may take the plates away.  Happened twice today during the same meal, I let the first guy take my meal plate but had to tell the second guy I wanted to stay longer and take a few more sips of coffee. It wasn't crowded; seems they could adjust the cleanup at less crowded times.
author: C J.

description:
The 3 stars is really about the convenience of the place when you need a bite and a break from the museum.  The location with table outside is perfect on a sunny day.  There is a huge dining area and the place is kept relatively clean with people constantly busing the tables.  Full ice water tanks with lemon for your disposal.  I made the mistake of grabbing one of the water jugs, but apparently it was a health code violation (oops)!  

Food-wise: I had their Pork Tartine with a bed of Arugala on top.  Yum!  But for $13 bucks, it's a bit pricey!  My friends had their veggie quiche for $12 a slice ( I think) and it was nothing fancy nor worth it.  The slice was pretty small too.  

Bottom line: There are so many restaurants on Irving (close by) that it's worth a drive out of the museum and come back if needed.  This place is really about the convenience.  I definitely think they have a decent selection of food, but it's kinda pricey.
author: Meshell C.

description:
Stopped by the De Young Cafe while on a date in Golden Gate Park! I was starving, so my boyfriend & I dropped by for a bite!

The first thing that struck me was the artsy-chic interior of the place. Think sleek, bulbous, softly glowing lights, smooth counter tops and thin metal chairs and you've got a sense of the cafe's atmosphere.

We ordered the chicken pot pie and a mochaccino. The chicken pot pie took about 10-15 minutes to arrive and man, was it good! It was really light and savory- the perfect flavor! The chicken was nice and tender and perfectly balanced with the flaky crust. I kind of wish the pot pie was bigger as I wasn't sure that it was completely worth the price. The dish itself came with a side salad, but seeing as I'm not the biggest fan of salads, my boyfriend ended up eating it for me.

Though I wouldn't say that the chicken pot pie was "completely" worth the price, I would actually go back for it! God, it was so delicious.. Also, while we were sitting in the cafe, a nice,  steaming plate of clams passed by and I might actually sneak back for those. I do love my seafood!
author: Lucy C.

description:
The museum cafe offers decent, yet expensive food.

Went to the de Young with a friend on a Friday night. I was hungry, so we decided to stop by the cafe. They had a 3 course prix fixe for 18$ and a soup special for $6. We decided to share both the soup and a prix fixe. 

Service at the cafe is a bit confusing. You pay at a counter, you have to get your own silverware, and drinks, waiters bring the food to your table, clear your plates during the meal, and walk around refilling your water. My guess is that having customers pay first allows them to serve faster or something. The staff was friendly and attentive. 

The best dish was the squash soup with coconut milk. The bowl was substantial and the soup was delicious. 

The prix fixe's first course was an arugula salad, which was simple and decent. The main course was a mahi mahi with polenta and collard greens. The main course was the most disappointing dish. The portion was quite small , it was not served hot, and was generally unremarkable.  The red velvet cake with white chocolate we had for dessert was quite good. 

We had a decent dinner, but I would have preferred a different menu at a museum cafe. I think they should focus on providing an assortment of fresh soups,  sandwiches, and pastries. It seems that they sometimes offer burgers and sandwiches on the menu. It is unfortunate I did not have those options when I visited!
author: Augusto T.

description: I stopped by after visitng the museum and ordered the veal meatballs AKA bitterballen that was accompanied by some cornichons and spicy mustard. I also ordered a side of french fries with garlic aioli and some fresh squeezed orange juice. At first glance, I thought these "bitterballen" were kind of small but I found myself completed satisfied with my order. I have never had this Dutch snack before but I am definitely hooked and returning for more during my next visit.
author: Jonnathan B.

description:
the food was definitely gourmet and moderate pricing ($15 lunch plate that was small but normal gourmet food sizing) but by far I absolutely love all the clearly marked vegetarian and gluten free options on the menu. they also had various salads etc for take out.  

I got a lamb meatball favabean dish and a flourless chocolate cake (both GF)
both were delish.

love the ambiance and super nice customer service.  the cake was so rich I had to pack half of it to eat later. 

It can get crazy in the cafe, but fortunately I was there on a very quiet sunday afternoon (it's quieter when there are not any special exhibits going on at the museum and the weather is sunny and warm) 

be sure to check out the great free sculptures and tunnel seat exhibit in the garden area!
author: Win H.

description: I was surprised at how much better the food was than I expected. Museum food is typically sub-par in my experience but the cafe had a decent selection. The menu wasn't extensive because you could get other things from the refrigerated area like pre-made sandwiches, salads, snacks drinks, etc. I had the roasted chicken breast and my dad had the short rib sandwich. Both were pretty good but a bit expensive at $15 each.
author: Bryan L.

description:
This place is actually really excellent for what it is. I'd even go so far as to say it's among my favorites as far as museum cafes go.

The huge dining area was pretty crowded, and as a result can be noisy because it's essentially just a giant room. 

I'm impressed with the efficiency of the staff, though. Someone greets you as you enter, and explains how to order food, which is a little jarring at first. But once you figure out where to go and how to order, and you sit, the food comes out super fast. And everything that we ordered was actually really good! The salads were not small, they had a bunch of fresh, flavorful ingredients, and the soup was very robust. My brother got one of the the ready-made sandwiches, which actually looked a little sad to me, but he seemed to enjoy it.

People keep saying the food selection is limited but I disagree, they have a variety of different fresh and healthy snacks, as well as basic American fare for everyone. I'd come back.
author: Anna H.

description: I didn't have high hopes for a museum café.  Usually the art is great and the food tastes like meals ready to eat.  The DeYoung Café was a refreshing surprise!  My husband and I both ordered the panzanella salad, rather expecting iceberg lettuce, and were ravished by the fresh greens, tomatoes, and light dressing.  The atmosphere was cafeteria-ish, with a nice view of an outdoor patio.  Too cold for Texans to eat outside, even in July.  During our visit to San Francisco we ate at a number of highly rated restaurants, yet I think the unpretentious DeYoung Café will be one of my favorite food memories.  Too expensive for what it was?  Isn't everything in San Francisco?
author: Patricia R.

description: My cell phone is screwed up and I could not check in to the party tonight (on Faceschmucks). What I will say about the cafe is that the wine was MUCH better than what they were selling for the Fashion Show, "24 years of More!" It was freaking amazing! Good times! And of course I love the De Young Museum! I just took my dad here last weekend...
author: Erin L.

description:
It was a good place to grab a bite when you are tired and don't feel like going any further.  The food is edible but forgettable.  Had the steak sandwich and they should of not put any steak on it.  The rest of the plate was good.  Also had the sausage meal.  For the high prices in that area, it was all pretty bland and with no spark.  If you have the energy go outside to the food trucks.  The meal will be better and leaving you with more money in your wallet.  
If you are tired and happen to be at the door to this place then by all means go in and put some grub in your belly
author: Jamie B.

description:
Tourist trap. Cappuccino tastes like dishwater (made from a machine) and costs $3.53. A single pear is $1.64. A small tart is 595+tax  a 250ml bottle of coke is 2.50+tax. You get the gist: anything here is 2x the price in a similar cafè in the most expensive area of the financial district.

You get the gist. Pack some snacks and drinks before getting to the de Young. It's hypocritical for a nonprofit to be taking advantage so badly of the people it's supposed to be serving.

Only good things: free Wi-Fi from the de Young and a great outdoor terrace.
author: Mike B.

description:
Waaay overpriced, and the food gave me a stomachache.

Ordered the mushroom dish with poached eggs, and it was something I totally did not expect.. Bleh... I can't believe I ate it, because it was kinda gross, but I was starving. I was especially disappointed that my egg was overcooked and not poached at all, and ended up with a hard-boiled egg consistency. My dad ordered the salmon, and it was just okay. The potatoes were... interesting. It had a hint of pineapple or lemon, I couldn't tell..

I think my family and I just ordered the wrong food. I should've gotten a quiche or something. On a positive note, their iced tea was good!
author: Janet H.

description:
Great mocha. Perfect balance of sweet and bitter. Right amount of foam. I ordered the sloppy Joe with fries and my friend had the salmon. The sloppy joe was grass fed beef, bread was fresh, and the fries was just a little bit salty. The salmon was good as well.

great view while having lunch and if you're here for the exhibit, great place to eat and then go back to the show!

minus one for the price though, it's really over-priced for the food.
author: Virlie B.

description: Not bad for Museum food, at least it wasn't as old as some the exhibits,(LOL) Food is good and the service was spot on, and with WiFi, a great place to rest your legs.
author: Bruce M.

description:
Good variety of dishes w/ a fresh modern approach. 

Yup, it ain't for cheapster's. Sooo many COMPLAINTS about the price of the food......maybe the cheapster complainers should bring a picnic lunch .... sandwiches of Wonder Bread, Bologna  &  Cheese Wiz or Craft "cheese" , or maybe grab something at Taco Bell and  "chow down" in the expansive outdoor space of GG park. Then they can visit the world class museum and extraordinary exhibits.....while burping/digesting & reveling in the fact that they didn't "over pay" at the De Young Museum Cafe'.

Everything I have had (sandwiches, salad's,  soup's) has been  great. It does feel like a temporary accommodation (the tent like thing), food is good. Maybe Dede W. can do something about the accommodation ? Please ? Pretty Please ?

LOL at some reviews of the De Young Museum Cafe, for at least one reviewer... "Service was CONFUSING" maybe the reviewer's condition is to be  confused but as an educational point....... it is a Cafe....Cafeteria style. ( I think I heard the same reviewer shouting " I could do that" in one of the art galleries) You do need to pick up your utensils, you do need to refill your water glass, you should not shout "Hey Ima from MODESTO and I get better service at McDonalds"

Ok, humor & sarcasm aside, it is a great place to have lunch.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
No, not cheap. However, I am always surprised that it is SO tasty and usually just right. I suspect that if you order based on eating something  filling, you may feel it is overpriced. If you can tolerate smaller portions and look a bit more carefully, there are many quality dishes that can amaze your palate and you may feel you are getting a good value for your food. I always come out satisfied and my wife LOVES this place [she is the fussy one]. 

I need to mention... you have read plenty of  reviews so you probably understand this is a large place serving lots of meals. It can be very noisy.. whatever [I am sensitive to noise but this doesn't keep me away].  

One aspect of the Museum Cafe is the staff and service. Every time we go I am surprised at how helpful, patient, and just plain nice they treat us here. I find this exceptional for the size, circumstance, and constant crowds they deal with. There are tons of great places to eat when we are in the city, but when we go to the Museum you can count on it that we will enjoy a meal here.    

Oh, the lighting isn't the best. It is fine for eating and enjoying your meal, but it doesn't do much for the images. The next time we go I will bring a "real" camera to try to give a better idea of how nice most of the dishes actually look!
author: mau r.

description: In the past I would have given them 4 stars for their delicious dishes (pasta, etc.), nice location, stylish dinnerware, and moderate prices. But in more recent visits only the fancy dinnerware and the nice views can be praised. The food quality is not the same and the high prices make $6 hot dogs from a street vendor seem like a bargain.
author: Luis C.

description:
I love the food here and it's always pleasant! 

Friendly staff, clean, and quick service. The food is a bit overpriced, but the taste and service compensates that.

Had lunch/brunch here before my planned "Girl With the Pearl Earring" exhibit. I ordered the chicken pot pie with the vodka lemonade (whoa, refreshing and delicious, and definitely gave a "kick"). Art and liquor, I don't see why not. My friend had the soup of the day (broccoli cheddar chowder?) which was delicious (my friend did not finish it, so I finished it for her).

Art and gourmet food, yum!
author: Alex C.

description: Just want to say that the manager, Mark (I think that's his name), at the cafe and the food, itself, are really great. I had "green" gazpacho recently and it was so good I had to ask him what was in it.  Wow. My compliments to him and to the chef. It's a great place to just relax as well, so you must give it a visit.
author: I R.

description:
Been coming here for 10 years and tonight was blown away by the cafe pre fix dinner. 
I started with a huge bowl of frisse gorgonzola walnut salad, then a generous portion of warm and spicy parsnip butternut squash curry over fluffy basmati followed by a dulce de leche that took me back to Buenos Aires. My husband had a Carne Adovado stew that had a unique spice I could not figure out. He started with salmon carpaccio fennel salad and also had the dulce de leche. We shared a carafe of rich spanish wine. This was all devoured under the stars on the patio. Our toddler was content for a good hour+ shoveling in fruit salad and macaroni. My only complaint was the staff (and there were 3 different people who brought us stuff) seemed irked at us for sitting "around the corner out of sight" - so they complained they did not see our number. Well then, why are there tables set w/cloth there welcoming diners to sit there? We were confused but disregarded it for the most part. I'd like to give the chef tonight a FOUR PLUS and the servers a 1 or 2. The greeter and cashier were professional and great though!
author: Amy E.

description: The café is large and very busy, and much to my surprise I enjoyed the pricey shrimp nicoise salad.
author: Terry T.

description:
Let's face it. Museum food will always be overpriced. It comes with the territory. But high priced bad food always leaves a sour taste. Luckily de Young stepped it up. The museum overhaul and new cafeteria, or should I say "Le Cafe" is pricey but at least its tasty. 
The pulled pork sandwich and creamy basil soup was good. You order up front but they bring the dishes to your table. There's self serve silverware, cold water, and coffee condiments in the front. I like the greenhouse-esque back patio part. Covered to protect you from the elements (especially the wind) but bright and sunny. 
Do be careful though, le cookie, looks pretty average but rings up as $4 at the till.
author: Naomi K.

description:
A dry and unimaginative pile of sliced pork and cheese.  It wasn't bad, but I wouldn't order it again.  Both my daughters refused to eat the children's hot dog ordered for them to split.

Coffee was good - free refill!
author: Rudy R.

description: Really good food options. The place is nice and clean. The seating could be a little better but hey they serve wine
author: Yaya L.

description: My Friend Ken and I came here for a snack while we were at museum and were pleased! What I really liked and we both noticed was how pretty and sculpturally presented the food was. Food was very good for a trendy hipster cafeteria style eatery. I would return each time I am at museum and I do recall the dessert which was deep chocolate was fantastic!
author: Julia Cameron D.

description:
The Croque Monsieur was good, I had never had one of those sandwiches before so, yeah. I liked how the cheese was melted all over the top and there was a different type of cheese melting out of the sandwich. I would order it again.

The quiche wasn't that great. Or at least the bite that I tried. I have had better. 

The little raspberry white chocolate cake was good. I've had better. 
The little carmel dulce cake was good. Creamy and light.
author: Laura B.

description:
Ate here yesterday (Dec 1). Maybe due to the rain it wasn't crowded. Yeah! They've taken down the awful plastic enclosure, so you can see the sculpture garden.

I had amazing Salmon Carpaccio. Fresh, delicious, excellent. Mike had rigatoni with squash, tomato, ricotta - also great. Coffee pretty good. Desserts looked divine, but we refrained.

We would have sat longer and chatted longer or got more food, but the chairs were testing our endurance.

If you're going to De Young or Academy or elsewhere in the Golden Gate Park, this is the place to eat.
author: Lynn M.

description:
Great service, very quick and courteous
Indoor/outdoor seating (not a pigeon in sight!).
they sell beer and champagne!

Menu was limited,
Had the Fish Stew and Rigatoni.
Fish stew was a bit bland, but loved the Rigatoni. It had big pieces of sausage and was very satisfying after spend 4 hours going thru the museum.

Great place to split a dessert or two with a friend after and discuss the exhibits.
author: Lynn T.

description:
I would like to update my review and let you know the outcome of sending the above letter to the de Young Cafe.  I was contacted by the head of the security staff and assured that they would take the proper steps so that this does not happen again.

I was also sent a letter from the cafe manager with a very nice offer to come back.  It was explained that the security team and the cafe are completely separate, which makes sense.  I do appreciate the efforts made by the de Young to rectify the situation.  I feel that my letter was taken seriously and it is their goal to to provide a positive experience to their guests.
author: Amber M.

description:
We have eaten here many times and was bored with the selection. The food is ok but pricey for what is offered. So this last time we brought our own sandwiches that we love from the Nugget Market in Vacaville. (mmm...portobello pannini!!!). 

We couldn't remember if there was a place to eat for those who brought their own lunch. Normally we would have gone outside to picnic, but it was a rainy cold day, so we ate by the windows in the cafeteria (it is really more of a cafeteria than a cafe). There were 2 people eating outside under a white tent cover, but we saw no heat lamps to keep warm with. 

It wasn't until we were mostly done eating that one of the bus boys told us we couldn't eat the food we brought inside the cafe. Outside? In the cold? No way! We finished our lunch and left. We are members, but there is not a special member seating area either.

So the cafe is your only choice while visiting the museum, unless it is a nice day, or you don't mind shivering while eating in the cold.
author: Karen J.

description:
This café is a glorified cafeteria. The food and drinks were over priced. It was like eating at a theme park. Really. That's what it was like, just less pre-teens and less pizza. 

I thought that the sandwich I ordered was delicious, but not $10 delicious. It wasn't even a fresh sandwich. 

I am sure the high prices help keep the extra wait staff that seem to do nothing employed, which in some way good for the economy... or... maybe it goes to keeping the museum operating... except that was what my $23 entry was supposed to be for.
author: Russell Allen E.

description: Amazing venue and food to match. The sculptures, food, service and did I mention desserts are amaaaaaazing.  One might not expect the food to be this good at a museum but it is Paris quality.  Hands down, love this place!
author: Elisa B.

description:
The food here seems overpriced, but they do use lots of local, fresh, organic ingredients, and I know that can drive the price up, so I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and assume that they need to charge me those prices to deliver yummy food into my face, and yummy yummy yummy it is...

I had a pulled pork sandwich. It was flavorful and just spicy enough. It came with guacamole on it, but I fed all my guac to Baby H., so I don't know how it would have tasted on the sandwich. He gave it five screams (stars). It came on a poppy seed bun, which was sad for me because I can't eat seeds and it didn't say on the menu that the bun was so seedy. I was able to peel the seedy bread off and enjoy my sandwich anyway.

My Mom got a Croque Monsieur, which she proclaimed to be amazing and oh so cheesy, and my Dad got a ravioli dish that he loved. For dessert, they shared a piece of chocolate cake that looked and smelled amazing. I had a tiny taste (I can't eat much sugar) and really enjoyed it.

I would definitely come back here, and I'd bring Baby H. again. There is lots of space, and they have high chairs. It also satisfies my most important baby-friendly restaurant requirement, which is that it be noisy enough that the entire restaurant cannot hear my noisy child.
author: Rachel H.

description: Yes, it's overpriced.  Terribly so.  I will say for just the atmosphere/quality of a museum cafe, the de Young cafe is pretty good!  I mean, just the fact that I can enjoy an Anchor Steam after a pleasant afternoon strolling around the exhibits is pretty extraordinary, I do say.  Going during off-meal times will ensure a calmer, more pleasant experience.
author: Mel G.

description:
The de Young Cafe is one of the unheralded gems of San Francisco. Nothing tops off a visit to the museum like the truly fantastic meals found at the cafe. This is not like your usual overpriced and bland museum food, but is instead interesting and creative dishes served in a beautiful setting. The menu is always changing, and generally influenced by the themes or artists of the current exhibits, adding a very interesting and fun element to the dining experience. The food is very fresh and very high quality, and the dishes and presentation are always perfect. The staff is very experienced, professional and exceptionally friendly. The cafe manager, Maury, is incredibly friendly, and is always seen running around making sure that everything coming out the kitchen is perfect and that every guest is happy. 

No visit to the de Young is complete without a relaxing and fantastic meal at the cafe!
author: Simon B.

description:
This place is way overpriced.  I paid $7.50 for a tiny portion of mac and cheese off the kids menu.  We paid $45 for the mac and cheese, sandwich, soup and 2 coffees.  

Granted, my mac and cheese was tasty, but definitely not worth the money with the tiny portion.

Eat before you visit the museum.
author: Aishling R.

description:
I gave them an additional star because of the way they handled the rush hour (lunch) in a rush day (free museum day). As you guess the museum and cafeteria were fully packed with people. 
Yes there was a long line and we had to go through table hunting, but considering the huge amount of people they dealt with, I was impressed by their ability to calmly and nicely control the traffic, process and deliver out the food orders, and keep the place clean.
The setting is a regular museum cafeteria setting, with the addition of the lovely statue garden view, and a hint of creativity given by the beautiful ceiling light fixtures.
The menu is not big, but it shows that it was thoroughly thought and has options for everyone - including some gluten free options. 
The lunch food is a three stars because it is okay - not bad at all but not exceptionally good. Definitely good enough for me and a friend to enjoy a small break between galleries walk. 
I would definitely eat here again on my next visit.
There will be a next visit for sure because this museum makes wonderful exhibit choices.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
How fantastic is the cafe?
Fantastic enough to warrant its own listing!

I adore this place, almost as much as the Legion Cafe. They have great coffee, tasty soups and sandwiches, and some sweets. Plenty of tables, tons of natural light, and depending on the weather, tables outside, always a plus!
author: Elise M.

description: I ordered Jasmine tea and my bf ordered latte. They use mighty leaf tea bags which was ok. The latte was sub par, too many bubbles in froth, and espresso was average.
author: Norma H.

description:
This Cafe is a great place to take a date, or even Mom! The food is locally sourced, well-priced and tastes great too. The setting is lovely, summoning a chic feeling and yet when you leave, you still have $$$ in your wallet. What more could you want?

You will feel tres cool dining here.

UPDATE 5/2006:
I wish what I wrote in my original review were still true. They've jacked up the prices while simultaneously reducing the quality. On the numerous visits I've made since the museum's opening, I have been disappointed in a MAJOR way. However, if they have the black bean chili on offer, it is worth a try.
author: Miriam W.

description: The Richard Diebenkorn exhibit of his Berkeley Years' work was truly amazing, but I have to say that a fine art day was just enhanced by the superior service and great food and wine we had at the outdoor cafe. The staff was so courteous and attentive. The options for special dietary needs such as vegan and gluten free food was present int he menu items. Their wine list is impressive for a venue such as a museum. Don't be shy and ask for the half carafe. All in all a great experience.
author: Artie A.

description:
Whoever is running this place is incompetent. It is of the most badly organized, badly run museum cafes I have ever been to. Coming here is  very stressful. I'll go to the cafe at The Academy of Sciences next time I'm in the area.

The pros:
- Great space - lots of potential
- Delicious brownies
- Very nice cleaning staff. I left my tickets to the Impressionist exhibition behind at a table, and one of the cleaning staff rescued it from the trash for me!

The cons:
- Completely illogical queueing (lining up) system.
- The ordering system does not work. The cashier took orders much more quickly than they could be fulfilled resulting in mistakes and unhappy customers. After seeing people behind me in line getting their coffees before I got mine, I had to make a complaint to get my order. One of the two lattes I ordered then arrived stone cold and it took them 15 minutes to heat it up! In short - FRUSTRATING!
- Expensive
- Overall unpleasant experience
author: Writer G.

description:
Ready to really shell out some cash for pricy museum food I was pleasantly surprised that the prices were reasonable and the food was GOOD!
