I got a Sloppy POPpy with a side of potatoes in honor of the Andy Warhol exhibit. I love how the museum cafe uses local foods. Makes sense! I believe some part of mine was from Yolo County. Moderately sized portions too- not that you want anything too huge for lunch. The food all came out right after we sat down to our table.
Something that I'll use for future parties/brunches is using big pitchers of water each with either lemon, cucumber, or orange. 
How creative! 

The menu is small but not the least bit confining. 
If one doesn't want to order off the menu they also have a large refrigerated section with prepackaged goods. 

I'm guessing the menu changes frequently depending on the exhibits and the seasons so I'll def go back for more!
author: Christine A.

description:
Definitely good food for a museum cafe. I would put it on par with the Legion of Honor cafe. 

A tad expensive but I don't blame them - they have a captive audience. The desserts are delicious and their sandwiches/soups are decent. It's a great space that is comfortable to eat in and not chaotic despite high turnover on the tables. 

Don't come here expecting great food, but come here if you want a snack and a place to sit and chat outside of the exhibits.
author: Madeline N.

description:
So my mother and I went to the Olmec symposium at the de Young with plans to go somewhere in the neighborhood for lunch since we had an hour and a half break. When the lunch break came around though, it was pouring rain. On top of not wanting to walk to the car in the rain, we also didn't want to lose the awesome free parking spot we'd been so lucky to find so we decided to try the Cafe.

There was quite a long line but they were very proactive and handed each person a menu well before we got up to the counter to order. We weren't expecting much more than a small lunch to hold us until after the symposium, and figured it was just going to be average 'cafeteria food' anyway. 

We both thought the chili verde with white hominy and guacamole sounded good and thought we'd split that and one other dish. Since it was a cold and rainy day, the soup sounded like a good choice to me, but while we were waiting in line I observed one of the wait staff walking by with a tray of three scrumptous salads. I instantly changed my mind and decided to try the jicama salad and I'm so glad I did! 

Both the salad and chili verde were wonderful. I was even impressed with the guacamole that came with it. The dressing on the salad was light and flavorful and the portions were perfect. Even the prices didn't seem bad considering how tasty and fresh the food was. I would definitely eat here again next time I visit the de Young.
author: Debi T.

description:
Came to the museum today with residents from a local hospital. Since it was cold we asked the cafe manager if we could eat in the cafe and she refused stating we were unable to bring in outside food even though I said we would purchase cafe items. We had no other place for the elderly and persons with disabilities to eat. After pleading with her she still said no. After speaking with the museum manager, the cafe manager agreed to allow us to eat in a separate walkway outside the cafe. This was nice but clearly the cafe manager does not understand how to support the elderly and persons with disabilities. It is always better to be inclusive and not make persons who are already "outcasts" actually look like unwelcomed "outcasts" sitting outside the cafe eating from their laps while they sit in their wheelchairs as "regular" customers get to enter. Where do we live again? Just another reminder some people are not a consciously developed as others and have trouble bending the rules to accommodate other human beings. 

We were grateful to have the indoor space and thankful for the museum staff for supporting the elderly and persons with disabilities. As for this poorly rated cafe, never again.
author: R R.

description:
Good stuff considering it's museum cafeteria food, but otherwise nothin special.

Paid a hefty chunk of change for what amounted to a soggy portabello sandwich. 

The outdoor seating was the best part of eating here, they have an expansive covered patio and a view of the sculpture garden. 

If you're trekking through Golden Gate park and didn't pack a lunch, this place will do! But bringing yr own picnic supplies is the better move.
author: Alan F.

description:
The de Young café suffers from very high prices, even for a museum cafe. A much better deal is found within line of sight at the more commercial-feeling, but better value, Academy Café.

I got a nonfat mocha, which was good but nothing extraordinary (unlike the spectacular post-Impressionism exhibit right downstairs). The raspberry pistachio cake, while delicious and having the pleasurable consistency of tiramisu, was dominated by raspberry at the expense of pistachio. 

Aside from the exorbitant price of the entrees (contrasting with the reasonably priced desserts), the biggest disappointment was the silverware, which, fresh out of the wash, was too hot to hold until allowing for a cool down period. We ordered a pulled pork sandwich and asked for it to be cut in half. Evidently their idea of this is to leave the sandwich whole and give us two plates and a dull knife with which to fumble.

For $23 plus tip, for a small, light lunch for two, the cuisine, service, and ambience must impress. Unfortunately, the de Young Café fails on at least two of these counts.  Do yourself a favor and check out the mint spring rolls at the California Academy of Sciences across the quad instead.
author: Conrad S.

description: Stopped by the cafe for a bite to eat during our visit to the de Young Museum.  I guess there are two ways to dine in the cafe. either order from a menu and be waited on or buy al a carte.  We chose al a carte.  We come to find out that the food was a bit expensive for what you get so  I got a Stoneyfield Organic Greek Yogurt for like $1.69.  I probably would have bought a sandwich or something but it was too early for lunch.
author: Michael S.

description:
Let's get something out of the way first: $15 DOLLAR PRIX-FIXE MENU!!!!!

Okay.  The prix-fixe consists of a trio of appetizers, your choice of entree, and a dessert.  Granted, the portions aren't humongous, but seriously, where else can you find such a complete meal for $15?  Hm?  What's that?  McDonald's?  *Slap*

Anyway, for the entree, I very much enjoyed my beef short ribs, although my friend who ordered the same dish had ribs that were too dry.  I also tasted the salmon, and that is tasty as well.

In conclusion, foor $15, their food tastes more like $20, so it's a bargain, and you get the benefit of sitting in a museum's cafe, pretending to be bourgeois.
author: jon y.

description: A solid mocha. . . the perfect blend of chocolate and coffee.  It was good and very close to great.
author: Omar C.

description:
I didn't expect to like this cafe at all. I figured it'd be overpriced cafeteria slop. But my stomach noises were attracting attention, so I broke down and decided to try it. I've since been back several times and have always been happy with it.

It is a little overpriced, but not as bad as you'd expect and the food is tasty. The service is quick and friendly and the napkins, water, and silverware are conveniently placed. They tailor their menus to be somewhat themed around what the main exhibits are, which is cool. They have a lot of choices, everything from fresh fruit, pre-made sandwiches and salads, and heavier meals. I'm usually hungry enough to go with the heavier meals. They usually have some good veggie options.

If you are visiting the De Young, I highly recommend stopping by the cafe. The dining room is bright and airy, and there's a cool patio outside. The chairs don't look comfortable but they are.
author: Crystal C.

description: Nice museum cafe. Ordered the pear, endive and arugula salad and it was delicious. If you ask nicely, they will let you add chicken to it and only charge around $2 extra. We tried to eat at the Moss Room, but alas, we did not have science museum tickets (see my review of the Moss Room). This was a fabulous alternative. Nice little selection of wines, too :)
author: Shelby D.

description:
Was stoked that I convinced my bf to go to both the Birth of Impressionism exhibit--and the museum cafe. I love the full museum experience--cafes, shops, etc. It is for that reason that I must give the cafe two stars. The semi-outdoor dining space was kinda cool, with views of the adjacent garden.

However, I promptly got food poisoning within a couple hours of eating the pulled pork sandwich. Obviously reheated, most of the meat was adequately warmed, but some parts were cold.  Not sure if I can attribute the poisoning to this or the potato salad that came with, which actually was quite tasty. Either way, it's more than likely that my food poisoning originated here since I had not eaten breakfast, and, including this day at the museum, I was not able to eat for three days. I was not looking to lose weight, so I didn't consider that a benefit.

It seems that too much of their efforts were put towards creating unique, "gourmet," museum food, and not enough towards the health of their patrons.
author: M A.

description: I had the most delicious parsnip soup here recently. Great garden setting. High quality food, if slightly inflated prices. Go for the daily specials!
author: Pamela S.

description:
While the food I've tried at the Museum Cafe has often been good, the prices are simply obscene.  And I'm not even talking about the prices of the food they prepare (since I have no way of knowing what their overhead might be), but the prices of stuff that they simply buy from a wholesaler and stick on a rack.  $8.50 for a 250ml. bottle of Chimay Red is laughably absurd.  It's $8.50 for a 750ml. bottle of Chimay Red in liquor stores, and those stores are already marking it up at least 100%.  

Their cheapest beer is $4.50 for a 12-oz. bottle.  How can the Cafe justify slapping on a 400-500% mark-up?!  The same goes for their other bottled and canned beverages, their packaged snacks, etc.  We all know that what the retail prices are of these things (so we can easily extrapolate their wholesale prices), so there's no mystery as to the Museum's outrageous profit margin.  

It's shameful that an institution that supposedly exists to educate the public and culturally enhance the community is instead totally elitist when it comes to food and drink, pricing many of their visitors out of the opportunity to stay within the building to eat, and instead forcing them to walk or drive many blocks to the nearest food sources on Fulton or Lincoln (presuming they even know where those are). 

Elitism isn't a bad thing, so long as it doesn't replace equal access. I have no problem with the Museum offering pricey wines, high-end cuisine, etc., but those should only be *in addition* to accessible, affordable food, not instead of it.
author: Curran H.

description:
The food area of the De Young Cafe looks much like a cafeteria, so I was really expecting cafeteria level food.  But wonder of wonders the food was awesome!

  I got the sausage bowl, with two different kinds of sausage, broccoli rabe, on a bed of creamy delicious polenta.  Wow, this had to be the best meal I've eaten in a museum/theme park/cafeteria setting!

  I also had a bite of the Marin Sun Farms(big fan) burger, and that too was exceptional.

  Bottom Line:  Maybe I was just famished from strolling around the exhibits all morning, there's only one way to know for sure.  And I'll defnintely be back for more!
author: Greydon U.

description:
Shame Shame Shame 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AOPkoNZf4gw 

Chefs de cuisine: Lance Holton & Josip Martinovic 
...should be ashamed of what is being served in your name at the De Young Museum Cafe. 

The wifey and I stopped in here to dine before enjoying the Tutankhamun ( www.tutsanfrancisco.org ) exhibit. We decided to do this together instead of subjecting ourselves to the wonderful circus of the 2009 Pacific Pinball Expo in Marin (see: linkhere). 

We spent $30 at the Cafe for two items. 

Price was NOT the issue. 

Presentation was NOT the issue. 

Execution and preparation were HORRIBLE! 

* Lamb Kefta ($12.00) - 
This is described as "Marin Sun Farms Rack of Lamb, Bulgur, Tomato & Eggplant Stew, Cucumber Raita". 

Sounds delicious, right??? But it was terribly unsatisfying. There was a total of two pieces of lamb (approximately 2 ounces of meat). The meat was overcooked, cold, and dry. It was like eating lamb jerky. Rack of Lamb should be moist, tender, and warm. What happened? All of these elements were absent after sitting too long under a heat lamp back in the kitchen, I guess... 

The dish also came with half a pita cut into 4 triangles, which was stale and dry. The tomato and eggplant was the only highlight but I was not prepared for the spiciness of this accompaniment to the dish. Get me a fire extinguisher! 

* Shellfish Pot Pie ($13.50) 
this is described on the menu as: "CA. Dungeness Crab, Wild Shrimp, CoHo Salmon, Lobster Gravy, Fall Veggies, Puff Pastry, little Salad". Again, great Bourgeoisie "aka bougie" description - terrible execution. Lite on the seafood. Underneath the beautiful looking Puff Pastry was an unexpected soupy and watery concoction masquerading as a Shellfish Pot Pie. 

This dish was served with a small bed of baby green salad and 2 pieces of Star Fruit. Unfortunately, the Star Fruit was starting to rot and brown significantly on its points. Shouldn't this fruit be cut fresh right before serving? How could you let this plate go out chef ???

When in Rome, do as the Romans. Our neighboring adult table-mates were eating off the kiddie menu which had Pizza ($7.00), Hot Dogs ($7.50) and Mac & Cheese ($8.50), which seemed like much better choices in the big scheme of things. 

Pluses: 
+ Free Serve-Your-Self Water. 3 choices. Iced, Lemon, and Cucumber-infused water. Served in 6-ounce glasses. 
+ Beer and Wine available 

Final Verdict: Be prepared to pay a premium for delicious sounding food that does NOT deliver. Save your appetite for some place much much better. 

Caveat Emptor...

#572 (#80@DYMC)
author: James G.

description: Museum food is usually highway robbery, but at least the robbery here was pretty classy and sorta finger-lickin'. We did the $15 prix fixe in the greenhouse out back. Cute appetizer sampler plate of a mushroom croque monsieur, truffle vinagrette spring mix salad, and a cuplet of clam chowder with a crouton afloat. I had been pretty excited about the croque, but it was cold and the cheese had congealed a bit against the tastless mushroom. Decent enough when you dunk it in the rich chowder though. The salad was pretty tasty, though all of us wished we had more of it considering how cheap greens are. I had the mussels with fettucine as my main and it was much much better than I expected. Lots o' mussels, lots o' juice, and lots o' herbage. The cheesecake at the end seemed like a freezer burnt afterthought, but considering that we were still ready for more food at the end, it went down the gullet.
author: Kevin L.

description:
A-OK about sums it up.
The entrance is a bit disorganized.  There is no table service, you must read your menu in line, then order at the counter, if you can figure out which line you want to be in.

It's not an inexpensive meal, but you're at a local attraction in San Francisco, what do you expect?  It wasn't our first choice, but not bad in a pinch.

That said, the pulled pork sandwich was divine, I really should have taken more napkins.  My friend was a bit disappointed with his Bleu Burger for it lacking any discernible amount of cheese.
author: Ken B.

description: Come hungry, leave hungry (if you're frugal like me).  The covered outdoor dining is nice, knowing how the winds can neutralize most sunny days in SF.  And it must make for a great event space, but the food is so, so expensive, that you should plan for nothing more than a light something between you and a friend to whet your appetites.
author: Jenn C.

description:
Nice place, lots of seating, the food is good and service was excellent, with a pretty smile.
Free coffee refill, choice of fine wine and beer, outdoor seating, and spectacular Golden Gate Park.
Lots of locals stop by for a quick bite, though, it may not be so quick if you want to seat and relax in a nice place.
author: Sing T.

description:
After a long day of soaking up art and being cultured, the time often calls for a lunch. The only place available is the De Young Cafe.

I went with my sister and a couple friends recently to see King Tut (which was kind of disappointing in my opinion). We got in for free because her art history teacher had a couple museum access stickers to both the Legion of Honor and De Young in one day. We visited both of them and worked up quite an appetite. So naturally we decided to eat at the cafe before we went to see King Tut. Got there and ordered a pull pork sandwich, a chicken breast sandwich, and 2 bottles of juice. You know what it came out to be? Around $25! The food was only okay, actually kind of cold even though they were supposed to be hot sandwiches and the drinks were warm when they were supposed to be cold. How ironic.

I was expecting more out of the cafe for the price we were paying for sub-par food. If you're desperately hungry I would advise you to order from the kids menu. From the looks of other people's orders, they got more bang for their buck.
author: Leslie K.

description: I think they had the best tomato bisque soup I've ever had.  It warmed me up on a rainy day.
author: Weston N.

description:
Way overpriced, as others have mentioned. Like, better to find a water fountain than bother with buying anything here. $10 sandwiches, $3 bag of gummy bears, $2 bag of chips that go for $0.50 elsewhere...Seriously, I've had way better museum food (think the Getty). Most of the stuff is already pre-packaged, and the stand outside some of the same stuff as the inside part of the cafe.
There are plenty of awesome food choices in SF...clearly, this place is not one of them. Stave off your hunger with some water and trek elsewhere.
author: Jan P.

description: There was a cockroach baby in the pastry case, but  I bought a cheesecake anyway.  It was pretty good.
author: Lempi M.

description:
OK, normally I don't buy food in places like this, but this morning I was busy, and in the chaos, forgot to actually eat lunch.  By the time we got into the museum, I was starving.  Off to the cafe.  

Holy merde, I thought lunches in Downtown SF were expensive.  $9.25 for a prepackaged sandwich?  Well, it was cheaper than the $12.95 one I had my eye on from the sit-down menu.  Two pre-wrapped sandwiches it is.  Got the turkey with cherry aiole - and you know what?  It was pretty darn good.  Not $9.25 good, but it was a good sandwich.

Learned my lesson and will make sure to eat ahead of time next time, but at least I know the sandwiches are good.  Overall, I saw people going back and forth - bring food to tables (for the table service menu) and cleaning the dining areas.  It's a nice cafe.  Just make sure to bring $$.
author: Denise M.

description:
I have been several times but last night's experience prompted me to write a review. I'm not much of a yelper because I think half of it is bull but people can get what they want out it.
So first of all, the service at the cafe is so delightful! The staff seems genuinely pleased to be there and help you out. I don't even expect good service at casual dining places anymore so it was a pleasant surprise.
Next, the food, which is what I am more critical of was pretty damn good. Had the 3 small plates for $15.00 which is a deal. My friend and I split the lamb kebab, the fries and the pulled pork slider with slaw. I left the table completely satisfied and not just because of the amount of food but it tasted great. The olives and caper berries brought to the table were delish too.
author: Melissa E.

description:
Avoid museum cafes at all costs - is usually my motto, or at least my when-I-go-to-museums motto.  Most are ridiculously overpriced and usually are just grab-n-go crap stuffed into cellophane.  $3 dollar apple, anyone?

Rant aside, this was the absolute best museum cafe I have ever been.  They actually have a thoughtful limited menu, which tasted more like non-museum-cafe food.  Although it seemed like all of San Francisco decided it was a good day to go to the museum, the food was a pleasant surprise.  Be aware that on an extremely busy day, there is not enough seating and you have to stalk diners as they are getting ready to leave their tables.

4 stars because in the realm of cafes, this was pretty exceptional.  1 off for the prices still being too high.
author: Alex N.

description: This cafe is a superb place to light for a delicious sit down meal or small snack. The menu is designed exquisitely around the current exhibits and features locally-sourced and high quality ingredients. I recommend having a full meal and asking the staff for recommendations. Maury, the Assistant General Manager has always provided enthusiastic, knowledgeable and spot-on recommendations about the menu choices and offered great explanations about why certain recipes were chosen. Eating here always makes my visit to the DeYoung Museum extra special, and I highly suggest adding it to your plan when you visit, you will be so glad you did!
author: Claire D.

description:
2 stars for the excessively high Cafe prices . 

I ordered a bottled soda (6 oz)  and it was $2.50.  I ordered one cup of pumpkin soup = $6.30.  Give me a break, the prices were 2.5 times the normal prices.  However,  I do love their expensive soups the best.  So I usually get the one size they have and ask extra bread.  They only bring you a tiny piece. 

The  well lit (all glass panels) cafe is nice with  artistically styled metal seats and some really nice artsy shaped plates,  but that does not take the sting out of their high prices for basic American food.  

The outdoor seating is nice now that it is partially covered (not heated).  Before it did not have an outdoor cover.  The sculptural garden is a blast to look at while you are eating.  

Yet, those food prices are too damn high.   You can bring your own food, but you should eat outside on the garden benches away from the cafe seating.  You can also check your coats and lunches in downstairs (across from the lower level elevators for free).

Free Perk:  
Free chilled domestic lemon infused water in glass pour-spout vessels with small clear cups.

(Note:  This cafe food is the same high priced food as the food at the Legion of Honor)  The food  & excessive prices also reminds me of the set up at SFMOMA.
author: Vanilla C.

description:
Why are museum cafe/food always so expensive?! It's like an amusement park!

But I must say, the De Young Museum cafe's shrimp and avocado salad is exceptional. It had tons of shrimp, half of an avocado, fig, endive, heirloom tomatoes, and much more. It was a very decent sized salad. The dressing was also very good. This will cost you $12! The vegetables were all fresh and ripe. This was probably one of the best salads I've ever had.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Walking through Golden Gate park in the rain, then walking through exhibits, then walking up and down stairs...
HUNGER.
If the weather would have permitted, I might have headed to  the city to grab a bite.  Probably would have been cheaper; however, it was pouring on Saturday and the Café seemed to be the sure shot.

The Café, with its wall of windows, offers your standard soups, salads, sandwiches, and snacks. Since Andy Warhol is one of the current  attractions on display, the Café is honoring him with a special menu. 
I ordered a "uncanny tomato soup" and Caesar salad combo. Although it was pricey, the soup-which was loaded with sour cream and fresh croutons-was the perfect fix for the cold rainy day.  Caesar was just those chunks of leftover white lettuce. I should have passed.   

Seating was difficult due to the rain.  I guess most sit outside. Luckily, they opened up an additional banquet room for more seating.


Thumbs up to the seasonal ingredients from local vendors.
Thumbs up for the great views.
Thumbs up for fresh water with slices of lemon and orange.

3 stars and I am sticking to it.  Oh yeah, the cube says stay away from the coleslaw.
author: Flor D.

description: Ok, so I've eaten here once or twice, grit my teeth and paid the price. But a few days ago I was here with my family. Ate a $10 tuna sandwich from the deli case and had an espresso (with soy milk). It tasted fine, but an hour and half later there was an ugly scene in my bathroom. Fortunately I'd made it home, having said I wasn't feeling well. Full-fledged food poisoning, I believe: chills and fever and the works. The only other thing I'd eaten that day was a piece of toast at home. So I am going to blame it on the cafe - perhaps the mayo was bad, or who knows what. I am going to blame them. And never eat there again.
author: Zena A.

description:
The facility is fine, and I expect museum food to be unreasonably priced. The line was moderately long, but that will vary -- when we left, there was no line at all. The harried cashier was nonetheless polite, and our food was brought (very!) promptly. As for the food, I'm not knowledgeable enough to say whether one of the "LES PLATES CUISINES" I ordered was wisely conceived, or the ingredients correctly chosen.

But I can figure out whether a salmon dish should be served hot or cold. This one was supposed to be hot. It was cold.
author: Bob S.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Shredded pork guacamole Sandwich = which was on a bun, so it should've been called a burger? But then again, technically, they're right because a burger is the beef patty right. Anyway. Technicality aside, it was pretty good. Not what I expected, but o well it all ended up fine. Came with some coleslaw, which was good. haha. Presentation was pretty nice for just a place to grab a bite. It was on a rectangular ceramic plates with like a drizzle of pesto looking thing for design. haha.

SERVICE:
Order at counter and servers bring it to you. The servers were really nice and thoughtful, but I wonder what their motivation is? Coz they don't get direct tips from the tables. But what was pretty cool was the water station, it had nice glass water... jug? Water jug? With a tap on it? Anyway 4 of those, regular, with lemon, with orange, or with cucumber. Wow how posh. 

ATMOSPHERE:
Well I wouldn't go out of my way JUST to eat here. But we were browsing around the museum's free side such as the bookstore / gift shop, and the tower. We were also walking around the Golden Gate Park too. So this cafe was a good pit stop, considering those circumstances. The cafe itself is designed nicely, black tables and black modern art deco looking chairs. Wonderful hanging fixtures inside colorful blown glass, which was really nice. Not just a blah cafeteria, but like an upscale one, if you will.
author: Angela L.

description:
WOW!! haha, this place was very surprising. For a cafeteria looking museum cafe I was expecting bad but convenient food. But I was pleasantly surprised!! The had a hot menu with items such as seafood pot pie, and mushroom and brie soup. Impressive!! They also had an assortment of salads, sandwiches, fruit as well.

I had as seared ahi tuna over quinoa salad and it was GOOD!! I only chose it since I needed something light, but I was pleasantly surprised. There were 3 FAT slices of ahi which tasted pretty fresh over a DELISH quinoa salad tossed with cucumber, carrots and edamame with a tarragon vinaigrette. Smallish portion, but not bad for $5.50!!

My sister had the seafood pot pie. We were pressed for time and the server assured us it would be out in 5-10 minutes. They had it out in 5! I don't know how...but they did. The puff pastry was perfect and flaky on the outside, and the inside was pretty good as well. There was salmon, shrimp and scallop in a lobster sauce, that was tasty and good. However, a majority of the pot pie was filled with air, which we discovered when the puff pastry deflated, and the sauce was a little too runny for a pot pie. For $10.50 they could have done a little better...

I would stop by again for sure if checking out an exhibit at the De Young. Yes it is pricey for what you're getting, but for the convenience it's worth it. You don't have to be scared of being completely ripped off here!!
author: Samantha S.

description: It's better than some of the restaurants in the area. Most of the time it has very good prix fixe specials on Thursday nights.
author: Brian J.

description: The food is always exceptional as well as the service. I just got snubbed by 4 museum curators and re found my calm in the kindness and customer service of the cafe.
author: Kitten M.

description: Pretty expensive but what else are you going to do when you get hungry at a museum? The cookies are big and delicious. Try dropping most of a chocolate chip cookie into a latte and then eating the mush with a spoon.
author: Kristopher A.

description:
I've been to this cafe three times. The first time my experience was just so-so. The food was decent but not overly flavorful. The next two experiences were much more positive with yummy, filling food. 

The food is definitely expensive (read "overpriced" but what else do you expect at a museum cafe?) and the portions are modest. 

The pastry is superb and the cappuccino is the best I've had outside of Europe! 

Staff is very helpful and friendly and the view of the sculpture garden is nice. I'd definitely eat here again and possibly make a meal of just dessert and cappuccino!!
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Too expensive for the meager portions.

You can tell the ingredients are fresh, but ... I still don't want to be paying that much for a meal and walk out without feeling satisfied. Looking at the other Yelpers on here, it seems like everyone enjoyed their meals. I guess I did, too, but ... I kept wishing we'd gone to eat at the museum across the street instead (the California Academy of Science). They have an AWESOME cafeteria with various cuisines, and portions that match the price. (Lunch will cost about the same at either museum, but if you want more bang for your buck, you'd better get to the science museum's cafeteria.) Their food is also organic (if you're into that stuff) and delicious. Hooray for their red curry with tofu! ^^
author: Bonnie L.

description:
Average Museum Food, Average Museum Price

Went here today with the mindset of "Well, this will be expensive, but we might as well just suck it up instead of hot-footing it all over GG Park." Having said that, we paid $25 for 1 "salad", 1 cup of soup, 1 bag of chips, and a bottle of coke. The soup - Tomato Bisque, was lovely (at $6 a cup, I was very glad it was edilbe). However, I'm not sure what happened, but we ended up with their version of a caprese salad (see picture). While good, it was no where near $12.50 good, and definitely needed a little more "ooph" in flavor and calorie content. As it's not on the menu, I'm not sure how it wound up at our table. We did order, and sit out on the patio for lunch. It was very lovely, but it would have been just as lovely to bring a sandwich and sit out in the Sculpture Garden. All in all, I would say the ubiquitous hot dog vendors would have given you more bang for your buck, and this place was just nothing special.
author: Anna B.

description:
They have a small plates menu, sold in units of 3 for $13.  Wish I could order four, or five, because they are quite good.  

There are sandwiches and desserts available on the line that aren't on the menu -- so, one's entire party has to file through the line, as opposed to sitting at a table and having one or two people get the food.

The desserts didn't have a price tag, so I couldn't figure out what any of them cost.  No price = no sale.  Employees all too busy to get one to tell me.

Meanwhile, the room itself is damned loud.  ("Cacophany" comes to mind.)  Sitting outside, even if it's under the rain tent, is a LOT less annoying.

Visited 11/27/09 evening.
author: Tom H.

description:
They offer great food for contemplating things, and an even better outdoor space for enjoying the food with friends.

I had a glass of local white wine with my pre-made (yes, I know, don't trust a meal in plastic, blah blah) vegetarian sandwich with zucchini, roasted eggplant, summer squash, romaine, and a spicy chipotle hummus on super herby focaccia. Perfect crispy crust, still glistening with olive oil and sea salt. Fact of the matter: it tasted fresh and delicious. 

Like the Academy across the way, they make a substantial effort at offering seasonal, local, organic foods and operate as sustainably as one can reasonably hope (compostable cups, fish is the "sustainable catch of the day", etc). The lady at the counter even brought my vino, in glass carafe, to my table when it wasn't readily available behind the counter.
author: Alex B.

description: The Cafe used to excellent before the closed, and ever since then, its gone downhill. The new cafe was great when it first reopened in the fall of 2005, but it hasn't been the same since.
author: Vicky L.

description:
Went to see the Egyptian Exhibit and got hungry, so we went to the cafe to take a break and eat. I did not order the cooked food, just got the to go stuff. A suggestion if you're planning to go. Order the food that is cooked because it is almost the same price as the to go stuff and looked much better.
My experience however was overpriced and not that good. I had the eggplant sandwich and fruit salad. That set me back almost $20!!! Sheesh! I could have gone to have a fantastic meal somewhere else.
Oh well, live and learn.
I will say the the seating area was beautiful and a pleasure to eat in. It was covered and protected you from the cold.
Exhibit was amazing!
author: Maurice A.

description: I'm not much of a sandwich person and I wasn't so impressed with rest of the menu either, so I ate some overpriced fruit and a seaweed salad. Pretty disappointed actually.
author: Jason L.

description: As with any museum restaurant -- here or abroad -- I expect overpriced food.  What differentiates the cafeteria at the de Young is that the food is actually quite good!  For example, we were at the museum on a somewhat drizzly day and were craving some good comfort food.  We ordered a rigatoni with sausage and white beans.  Very filling and very appropriate for the cold San Francisco day after seeing the Masters of Venice exhibit!
author: Jacqueline C.

description: Why is this place crowded? I don't get it. Waited in line for what seemed like forever, only to see a salad in a plastic box priced at over $15. Are you joking? People must be brain dead from the lack of oxygen in the stuffy new building to actually eat here.
author: Larina M.

description:
Took a break from looking at FASHION to eat some food.  Sure, it's expensive.  It's a museum cafe, I expect this.  

Had the soup and sald ($9.00).  The broccoli cheddar soup was good, filling, and fell more on the cheddar side of things (I was OK with this).  The caesar salad was heavy on the dressing, but again, I was OK with this. Washed it down with a glass of pinot in some nice, stemless glasses.
 
I actually quite enjoyed this meal and liked the flower on our table.  I've already forgiving them for putting the salt and pepper in the wrong shakers.
author: Cory G.

description: Came here recently to check out the Picasso Exhibit and the bf and I were hungry. We needed to grab something to eat and make it rather quick. The food here wasn't as expensive as I thought it would be. I had the soup of the day and he had this really good quiche. They brought the food to our table and we had about 15 mins to eat it.
author: Lynn C.

description: Has a pretty good assortment of food, with fresh fruit, pasta salads, desserts and also sandwiches and a made-to-order menu. Pricey, as most museum menus are, but also a bit upscale in terms of the food selections and quite tasty. We stopped in for lunch on a cold day in the park, we weren't even visiting the museum.
author: J E.

description:
The outdoor seating is worth the 'price of admission'.  The landscaping and sculpture, the random human elements are all soothing respites for the eyes and the soul.  

Nurse a coffee and cookie, and indulge your camera.
author: Mutant O.

description: The cafe was alright.  They have their common snacks such as cookies, chips, etc.  with salad and sandwiches. That are very pricey! Drinks would be water, soda and some common lattes like mocha, hot chocolate, etc.  I just came here to grab something to eat real quick since i was hungry from the 2 hour walk around the museum.  I ordered the linguini bean soup and it was pretty good but not worth it for a price such as $7 for a cup. But these prices remind me of airport prices because its within an attraction building.  Best advice, buy food outside or bring your own cause you'll save more money!
author: Sharjah M.

description:
After viewing a lonely Warhol upstairs I suddenly had a craving for soup. Not sure why. I ordered soup (carrot ginger) and a side of mac and cheese (after adding a touch of salt) and both were done fairly well, better than expected.

Not crazy about the decor (I only really liked one or two of the lamps) and the chairs are more comfortable than expected except for the part that sticks into your spine. Lean forward, eat, get refreshed and then get going again.
author: Mister X.

description: Great soup - a popular choice for many. The pulled pork sandwich was large, messy and delicious. The line becomes confusing since there are two places to order and some of the items are self-serve.
author: Keith R.

description:
Hello. $7.00 hot dogs. $12.00 grilled cheese sandwiches. I think not! We were hungry after seeing the beautiful Chiluly exhibit but not that crazy. I know museum food can be pricey but this was eye-opening. We recently ate at the museum cafe in the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and had gourmet sandwiches for $8.95. More reasonably priced. It's hard to justify a $7.00 hot dog for a kid, with no ball game in sight!! 

PS  Outside the museum, about a block away, was a hot dog cart with.$3.00 hot dogs!
author: Lulubelle L.

description: I like the fact  you can enter the cafe without buying a ticket for the museum, but that's about it.  I was waiting in a horrendous line w/ gf for the Academy of Sciences for the free Wednesday and we got hungry after waiting 2 hours.  So I ran over to the De Young cafe to pick up some thing to hold us over and they happened to be their sandwiches.  We had the salami sandwich and the prosciutto sandwich.  Firstly the salami sandwich tasted like an oscar meyer baloney sandwich, bleeh.  Then the prosciutto sandwich was super salty, but not because of the ham, because of the canned roasted red peppers i believe.  Also very pricey here, but we didn't have much of an option.
author: Spencer W.

description: Ok. museum food-filled with a variety of light salads and sandwiches. ALSO with heavy foods-hot dogs and burgers. What could go wrong? :O) Prices are a bit higher since we are in the museum, but eating outdoors  and looking at art on a sunny day in the shade with family: PRICELESS!
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description: I came here to have a glass of wine after a long day of exploring. The white wine had a clean, crisp taste and was perfect for the occasion. The cafe is a great place to meet with a friend before or after visiting the art gallery. I took one star away because the food selection available to me was very limited.
author: Davida B.

description:
I must applaud the staff at the DYM Cafe.  I went to the cafe one busy morning with my 11 month old twins, one strapped on to my chest and the other on a stroller.  Upon entering , without even asking, I was offered help by the staff and they set up two high chairs on a table for me.  To my surprise help came again when I was ordering and a staff member carried my tray, grabbed flatware for me, and walked it over to my table.  It was very nice of them to do so.

And the food was great.  I had the duck sausage with polenta.  I loved it my twins loved it.  And it was so fantastic their varieties of flat water they offered, free, with lemon, oranges, and mixed fruit.  Free flavored water is awesome.

Top notch cafeteria food and excellent staff.
author: Enrique L.

description:
Far better than the usual museum food. I had a coffee as well when I first arrived, and it was delicious. Though the mug was horrible - the little finger holdy thing is actually painful to use. The lunch was yummy, I grabbed some of the pre-made stuff and had a salad with filet mignon on it and a couscous salad on the side. They had a lot of other options that looked awesome, including fresh stuff like pasta, other salads, and sandwiches. The prices were decent too, and the staff was really helpful.

Oh, and you're eating among some pretty famous pieces of art, so that caps the 5 stars for me!
author: Sarah K.

description:
The De Young cafe within the museum looks more like a college cafeteria than a welcoming restaurant.  While open and airy, with a view of the Golden Gate Park, the chairs are made of a not-so-comfortable wraught-iron, and the tables are flimsy aluminum.  

The food, however, tended to be better quality than the furniture in the restaurant.  I ordered a turkey sandwich which was made with smoked turkey and fresh vegetables.  The black bean soup, while average in taste, was served hot, in an artistic bowl, and was quite a pleasant treat on the cold day. My friends ordered the cheeseburger (which took over 30 minutes to be served! It doesn't take thaaat long to make a burger, right?), and the Asian salad (though drenched in dressing, it was still very flavorful).

I guess this cafe is decent in it's own right, and offers some tasty treats for a museum cafe, but I'd vote to eat before you go to the museum...or if you do eat at the cafe, make sure to not get the prepackaged food, and instead, order off of the menu.
author: Anjali M.

description:
So I'm opening an order at the counter gourmet lunch rush restaurant soon. Obviously I'm market researching my way through many meals. This place SUUUCKS. Here's the rundown:

*Food: 3 or 4 stars. Looks like they change the menu a lot, our sammiches were inventive for sure.
*Prices: 3 stars. It's a museum, so you know you're going to get pinched on food & in the museum store.
*Service: 1 star. We took over a table that hadn't been bussed. There was a gnarly half eaten pasta dish among other dirties. We finished and pushed our plates onto the pile. Sorry for the next folks, but the odds are getting more in your favor that a busser will be by soon.
*Overall layout: Negative 6 stars. They pumped a ton of money into the aesthetic of the place, and I suppose someone was paid a lot of money to design the traffic flow for deciding/ordering/paying, but it's a mess. We were there on a pretty slow day, but there was mass confusion waiting to get to the registers.
author: Tony S.

description:
This is good food, and definitely better than your standard museum cafe fare, but it still has museum prices that are much higher than the food. 


I still am kinda curious what a 9$ hot dog tastes like....
author: Mark A.

description: 13$ for a tiny piece of luke warm quiche and some arugula leaves. Are they serious! It might have been ok if I hadn't been starving or the piece had been bigger. I was still hungry when I left and there was no way I was going to wait in that long line again for more overpriced food.
author: Diana T.

description:
holy jeebus. $15 prix-fixe meal tonight + free admission to de young = heaven!

I couldn't believe it was only $15. but it was! plus a baby carafe of jade mountain chardonnay for $7. the cafe is charming with the soft glowing orbs above the extraordinary plastic chairs. You do stand in line to order your food, but it was delightful food, lovely and perfect after seeing the Birth of Impressionism. 

For the appetizers, I got three little portions: a tomato leek and brie soup (hot, sweet, creamy), a simple salad of greens and fennel and truffle oil (savory and earthy), and a mushroom sandwich (perfectly crisped). 

For the entree, I got the short ribs with creamy polenta, with fresh herbs and root veggies in the sauce. rich and light and a great portion size. I was pretty stuffed after the first two courses.

The dessert was a pecan square in raspberry sauce. It wasn't as good as the first two courses, but at that point I could have been served mud and said "well done! four stars!". (the fifth star was because it wasn't mud). 

If I go to the De Young again, I will definitely come on a $15 prix-fixe night. 

(the price! still awe-inspiring!)
author: Jade L.

description:
Came here today on a Sunday afternoon for some coffee and a little treat. Gotta say, this place is kinda like a circus. You would think that a museum cafe would be calm, not stuffy, but not overly hectic either. It felt like a madhouse today and all we ordered were 2 lattes and an oatmeal cookie. 

Mebbe because it is a Sunday and everyone seemed to be there grabbing a late lunch, or maybe the layout is a little confusing, two registers are posted on either end of a refrigerated section holding salads, sandwiches, drinks and snacks. You can also order at the registers for stuff off of their menu, which we haven't but are thinking of coming back for. Then you're off to find a seat in crowded dining area where the runners/servers/bussers are either understaffed or too slow at doing their jobs. We ended up sitting outside enjoying the sun and pretty darn good lattes. But inside would have been nice as well because of the candy drop looking lights and large windows along all 3 walls. 

In any event, we have been here on slower days and it truly wasn't as bad as I've described for a Sunday afternoon. We definitely would come back again for the coffee and the environment, just not on a Sunday. 

Lesson learned.
author: cora j.

description: Wow, you people are picky! Have you ever tried to sit down and eat at any major museum anywhere in the world? OK, De Young is not one of the high-profile museums, but it's San Francisco, where locals and tourists are equally willing to pay. First of all, the place is huge, meaning that you may sit down without waiting in lines. The outdoor sitting is overlooking sculpture garden. The plastic covering the patio is quite ugly, but it does help with San Francisco chilly breezes. The menu is simply gourmet! As to the prices... Where else you could find a prix-fixe three course dinner for $15 per person? Amazing!
author: Lana L.

description:
With the promise of fresh produce and local creameries and cattle ranches, all ingredients within 150 miles of the museum's kitchen, I was disappointed with the meal I received at the de Young cafe. Not that I was expecting much to begin with (it IS museum food), but I was hoping that the restructuring and reopening of the museum itself might raise the quality of the dining.

Unfortunately, what I found was the same old museum food, just a bit fresher and more expensive. I had the Pasta Vera Cruz which was overwhelmed by the amount of cilantro mixed in, and even though I love cilantro even I had to admit it was too much. The mac'n'cheese was bland and congealed. The spinach salad, which had looked promising with figs, chili pistachios, and queso fresco, was served cafeteria-style in a plastic container and the spinach alone was "fresco." 

The only things I enjoyed tasting were the wine and cocktails I had pre-dinner at the open serving table in Wilsey court (not part of the cafe). Bottom line, you can enjoy the full cash bar on Friday nights, but order cocktails only and go to dinner elsewhere.
author: Kimberly C.

description:
As much as I like coming here during my visits to the museum, there are certainly things that can be improved.

The good:  The look and feel of the space is great, in keeping with the inspired architecture of the revamped museum.  I applaud them for trying to make "sustainable" food and not dishing everything out on plastic or paper.  Eating outside is really nice if you're there on a sunny day.  

The not so good:  During the lunch rush hour it can be pandemonium.  People get confused about the difference between the left and right stations (there's no difference) for ordering/paying.  The placement of the grab and go station exactly where both lines diverge causes even more chaos as people try to move through to look at their choices and lose their place in line (or end up cutting in front of other people).  Improved crowd control would be a good thing - a lesson from other cafe style places that might be useful here is taking orders while people wait in line to pay.   Also many places don't make you sign for a credit card bill below $20 anymore, but the DeYoung insists on making your put your John Hancock on the charge slip for that $2.50 bottle of soda, and that just slows the line down even more.  Also I think it's crazy that the cashiers are basically manning the espresso bar and pulling pastries out of the cases.  An operational efficiency expert would have a field day here.  


The food:  I found the turkey BLT pretty dry.  I enjoyed the hummus wrap ($10.00) much more.  French fries ($4.50 I think) are crisp and not oily.  The prices are high, but I don't have an issue with them since this is really a convenient place to eat while visiting and there's no obligatory tip on the table.
author: Don L.

description: I was bummed that they didn't have hamburgers this time I went, but I had the mac and cheese. It was so good! They don't use traditional cheeses. I think it was made with Gorgonzola and Parmesan. Yummm...
author: Mahta P.

description: Up at the de Young to see the Tut show before it closed at the end of the month, I dropped by the café to grab a quick drink. Was a little surprised how a bottle of Coke and bottle of organic lemonade wound up costing me nearly $6--yikes! I would have been a little more forgiving if our drinks had been cold--clearly they need to lower the thermostat on their cold case since our drinks were room temperature. But the final straw--as I'm about to open my lemonade, I see the expiration date: Feb. 24 2010. They were serving drinks a month over their expiration date! I complained to what looked like a manager, and while he gave me a new drink, there was no apology for the mistake nor any promise of checking the cold case to ensure other diners didn't get expired drinks. Take my advice--check your drink next time you pick up something to go from the café's cold case!
author: Raul N.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by the quality and flavor of the food here.  I had the Chinese Chicken Salad and enjoyed the combo of flavors. The chicken was cooked just right - moist & fresh.  Two friends had the Salmon dish and also commented on how flavorful it was & how the fish was cooked just right. Prices are high.

The outdoor seating area is a great hangout spot on a sunny day.
author: Barbara P.

description: I had a tasty soup of the day, Broccoli Cheddar. I also sipped an Earl Grey tea, and was pleasantly surprised to find soy milk offered. I was unclear on all the offerings though- you get one menu and then have no idea about the daily specials until you get up to the register and the staff is rushing you to order.
author: Wanjiru K.

description:
Usually not too disappointed with their fare here. Recently, I had the meatloaf sandwich with fries and it was outstanding. Another time, I tried the $8.95 Niman hot dog and that too was pretty good, even though my parents, to this day, would thwack me on the head if I told them I paid almost nine bucks for a hot dog. "But Ma!--It had fries too!" Both times, I bought a dessert---part of the diet angst plan-- and was disappointed. One time I bought a large snickerdoodle cookie...that was too blaaah. Another time, I got an ass-reaming priced mini carrot cake (it LOOKED good)... that was too tasteless and dry. This last time, I got a large chocolate chip cookie...I mean how hard is it to screw up a chocolate chip cookie? Wrong. Coconut oil. Tasted old and pretty chewy. If I waited a few days, I could resole my Birkenstocks. While their main dishes are pretty good, they need to get a new vendor for the desserts. Don't they know that art makes people want to eat sweets? gah?! 

As for the ambiance...well....Its like a cafeteria. If you sit next to a loudmouth at the next table, you will be in on the conversation whether you want to hear or not. I had to hear an obnoxious old couple at the next table bellow about their trips to Mexico and their knowledge of Ancient Mexican art since they took that trip from the cruise ship...and then go on about those "Vietnamese" artists and how much their art blossomed because of the French. I was envisioning throwing my cookie at them.
author: Barb B.

description:
$8 for a peanut butter and jelly sandwich.

OK. It is organic whole grain bread.

OK. So the jelly and peanut butter is organic too.

But brotha, PLEASE! Unless that peanut butter was hand ground by Gerard Richter or the jelly was hand squeezed by Kiki Smith, there is not need to charge that much! 

If I came here with a kid, and he ordered the PB&J, it better be the best Goddamned PB&J ever.
author: Jackie I.

description: This is a very typical Museum Cafe style place. Lots of people, lots of seating... so it kinda works out ok. The food here is hella expensive. However, the Chai Tea Lattes we got were only 2 bucks a piece. Go figure. Down side was they were pretty light on the Chai, sort of like drinking warm foamy milk. On a cold, rainy day, I'm surprised this didn't put me to sleep there and then.
author: David M.

description:
Way too expensive for what you get, which is totally hit-or-miss.  The Asian chicken salad comes with dark meat and some skin/gristle--not what I expect in that dish--and it's drenched in dressing.  Seemed very home-made, though I think a lot of home chefs might put more care into their cooking.  The shrimp salad with rice noodles was also rather disgusting--noodles with a consistency of cardboard seem very out of place in San Francisco.  

The atmosphere is the best part, but a word of warning to parents:  The Apple art installation, despite being toddler-sized and very inviting to the little ones, is not to be touched, lest you suffer a tongue lashing from one of the museum guards.
author: Jennifer T.

description: I really liked hanging out in their transparent canopy on a rainy day. It was nice to be able to sit in the rain without getting wet. The hot chocolate they do is extremely good!
author: Nantas S.

description: My $10 pre-made roast beef sandwich was not enjoyable.  They just didn't seem to have a good operation going.  All people want are simple things and they don't have anything simple.  They tried to go classy and it's not working.  The sandwich did have a ton of good quality beef, but the taste was bland and the bread was not to my liking with seeds I didn't care for, but they didn't state the bread it was on so I didn't know.  If you go to the museum, bring a snack and get a better meal elsewhere in the city afterwards, or eat before going.
author: Marc S.

description:
Most museum cafés are pricey and with limited menus. I've always thought that the Legion of Honor and the de Young have good food. The last couple of times I've eaten at the de Young, however, I've noticed that the portions get smaller and smaller. Two of us on Father's Day had the salmon burger (very good), but the wild rice accompaniment was almost a joke.  Just some small crudité would have been welcome as a garnish! Three of us ate for $40.00 including a modest tip.

Salads are nicely prepared (too small!), and the drink stations are a good touch. Tip: During special exhibits, needless to say (but I will) schedule your lunch between 11:00 and 11:30 to avoid the crush. On Father's Day, we were lucky that at 12:45 there wasn't a long line. We had planned to see some of the Impressionist show, then leave and return after lunch. However, the "no-exit, no-bathroom" policy killed that idea, so we ate at the museum. (During Bouquets to Art, we spent almost more time on line than we did looking at the flowers!)

If at all possible, eat outdoors, then exit to the sculpture garden (and don't miss the tunnel!). On a sunny day, you'll enjoy the lawn.
author: joyce h.

description:
at a place where you order your food.  get a flag.  have the waiters find your flag and give you your food.  you would expect fast service.  NOT.

we waited 30 minutes for our food.  we ordered a cheeseburger.  tomato soup.  roasted corn.  mac and cheese.  the mac and cheese came first and it sat there for 30 minutes.  the waiter actually came by once with a tray full of food.  with what looked like OUR food.  the burger, soup, corn.  but then it was whisked away.  tray after tray came out of the kitchen and into peoples bellys and still no sign of our food. we asked the lead or head looking waitress or hostess and she told us that she would check.  she came back and told us it was on a tray that was on its way to us.  the tray passed us and was ... empty.  we waited some more.  we wanted to stomp over there and demand a refund.  but then suddenly out of the sky and heaven ... our food came.
author: claudia y.

description: I'm usually generous with reviews. If I could give this place a zero, I would. I purchased a veggie sandwich (selected from a cooler) for almost 10 bucks. This was basically a bunch of yellow squash stuffed between 2 pieces of limp, soggy foccacia. Expensive, awful food, and you have to wait to get in. My husband had some mediocre squash soup, he wasn't impressed either. Make sure you eat before you go to the museum. Seriously.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
Another May 2010 vacation review... A museum cafe (clearly), though a bit better than average. We hit this up after spending some time in the Botanical Gardens (in the rain) and in the museum itself. Grabbed a bite to eat here instead of on Sunset proper as my travel partners were in dire straits.

Roast beef sandwich w/ "onion goo" (who the hell puts that on a label), side salad of tortellini w/ sausage, and a soda - $18. Not horrible, but not the prices or flavor of a taqueria, which is where I was hoping to lunch (and dinner, and breakfast...).
author: Mike R.

description:
Food is not good. I had a roast beef sandwch and it was the most bland tasting sandwich I had ever had. But it did look nice. Glad I ordered fries becase that's what I stuffed myself with before walking through the museum.

My friend had a cheeseburger and said it was also bland. How can you do wrong with a burger?!

It is a good place to just sit and talk with whoever it is you've gone to the museum with. Very airy with glass all around so you can take in the sights while eating your bland food.  My sandwich (around $10) and fries (around $4)  came close to $15 so I guess I was paying for the convenience of eating at the museum. Next time I'm just ordering fries or eating before I go to de Young.
author: Wendy B.

description: My husband and I had lunch at the de Young Cafe yesterday.  He ordered the smoked fish platter, which was nothing special and consisted of a couple pieces of smoked fish, some slices of bread, a couple deviled eggs, and small pickles.  I ordered the ham and cheese sandwich, which was a grease pit.  I could swear they soaked the bread in melted butter.  They should rename it the "heart attack sandwich," as it consisted of a gazillion grams of sat fat.  It was accompanied by a bunch of tasteless plain greens with nothing on them.  The next time we go to the museum, we'll have a late breakfast and save our appetites for one of the nearby restaurants on Clement St.  Consider yourself forewarned: the food is horrible and way overpriced.
author: Nancy S.

description:
$15 for 3 tapas on Friday nights is an easy, nice, low key dinner after enjoying Friday Night at the museum.  Nice place to go with the kids, they are happy to run around the lawn and feast on the mac and cheese, and... enough space you don't bother others even with crying kids twins.

Can't thank the chef enough for putting a real effort into the menu, it shows, we love it.  Beer and wine too.

braised beef and cheese polenta - yummy
seared tuna - nice
pulled pork slider - yummy
split pea soup
author: Thomas B.

description:
I was here on the early side, so the line was rather short and it was really easy to find a table. However, within 15 minutes the line was quite long and all tables seemed seated.

I had the pasta with asparagus and it was just fine.

I don't think I would go here unless it was off-hours (noon is a no go) but it's a great place for some simple food within the museum and golden gate park.
author: J B.

description:
Just okay food. The beef barley soup (of the day) was tasty but a bit on the salty side. The salmon tasted on the cusp of being past its prime.

My friends reported that the bread on their reubens was stale.
author: Charles B.

description:
Whoever designed the flow of traffic in this cafe is not a very nice person.  This place is so chaotic.  

Here's a tip. . . .Ignore everything in the cases.  Just go up to the cashier and tell him/her what you want.  Don't take a pre-made a salad from the case.  They'll make you a fresh one.  Then just sit down and they'll promptly bring you your food.

I had the Asian salad.  It was good.  It had a lot of dressing on it but luckily the dressing was yummy.  The bf had the turkey sandwich which he loved.  We shared some yummy fries.  I was starving as I had just worked out so I had the PB&J as well.  It is served on super yummy bread.  

All in all if you do get overwhelmed by the chaos of ordering you will likely enjoy your meal.
author: Jeff P.

description: overpriced average food, and a chilly sterile cafe seating area.  A big group of us saw the Impressionist exhibit (Part I), and we all ate together here afterwards.  Not terrible, but the food was not memorable.
author: Ashley E.

description: We were very disapointed by our visit today. We have two young boys and tried to get a spot on the patio (which was entirely empty by the way) so we could have the stroller next to us. The hostess refused and did not let us in. She said we had to "chain" the stroller outside! Stay away if you have kids!
author: Reza M.

description: What a bad experience with the food.  The space is lovely but the "Italian Panini with prosciutto and cheese" was one of the unhealthiest and worst things  I have eaten since I last tried McDonalds years ago.  The only piece of prosciutto I could find was about the diameter of my thumb and the thinness of a razor blad.  There was some red stuff which had no taste and, what I suppose was metled cheese, had the taste and consistency of warm mayonnaise.  On the plus side the coffe  and the bread was fairly good.  I only regret that I didn't have the presence of mind to take it back and ask for something else.  And this sandwich, about the taste level of McDonalds and probably even unhealthier, cost about $12!  Stick to the museum and skip the food.
author: Lee R.

description:
i'd much rather study here than at barnes and nobles. the vibe is uber cool with warped, colored glass light globes hang from the ceiling like a galaxy and bossanova music playing in the background. and each table has their own chrysanthemum. how sweet.

get their soup of the day, it's only $2.40 for a sweet bowl and you can have as much bread as you want. oh, and their scone is legit. none of those starbucks bitch-cake varieties. on the side, they have these pitchers of fruit-infused water. so you have the choice of lemon, lime and... grapefruit?

BUT who the hell would pay $10 for a ham sandwich?
"krys, it's what's in the sandwich that makes it pricey..."
reading the label: ham & cheese. hmm. am i not getting something here? if i went to the grocery store right now, i can buy ham, cheese and bread for $10 and make FIFTEEN sandwiches.
"but krys, their ingredients are whole food and organic."
fair enough. i bought the sandwich. i regret it everyday since.
author: krys s.

description:
Well overall I am pretty happy with my lunch here at the Cafe. I did not try the "cooked" or "menu" based food. Instead I opted to check out the "grab what you want" which I thought was perfect for a nice lunch. 

They have pre-made sammies, chips & cookies, nice looking salads; from couscous, pasta, and leaf salads. They had a large selection of drinks (soda, teas, coffee, and fruit drinks). 

Overall not to pricey and a great quick meal. I would come back and snack here again. Besides, you need fuel before browsing the exhibition!
author: Jay D.

description: This place ain't bad for a little afternoon snack and glass of wine before you go to see an exhibit. I suggest ordering off the actual menu rather than grabbing some of the premade stuff. The outdoor area is really nice but there's generally a lot of families there so lots of kids running around. But on a nice day it's probably a good spot to hit while exploring the park and I think you can go in without paying admission to the museum. (Don't hold me to that cause I could be wrong).
author: Kandace K.

description: Food was good, if overpriced.  We decided to have lunch here rather than leaving the museum.  The menu was limited, but had some good offerings.  Or maybe it was too hot for many of the things on the menu to sound good, like mac 'n' cheese.  Nina says the menu at the Asian Art Museum is more extensive and interesting.  Larry ordered a hamburger and Nina, Alan and I ordered their banh mi, made w/ local rock fish on a torpedo roll.  It was expensive at $12 w/ nothing else on the plate, but it was tasty.  They sell bottled water but they also have pitchers of water and glasses so you can serve yourself and not create waste.  We liked that.  There are also pre-made sandwiches and salads to grab and go.  Fresh fruit costs $1.50 each piece, which is exorbitant.  Servers and probably cooks were overwhelmed w/ the crowds, which were huge, inside and out.  It took almost half an hour for the sandwiches to arrive.
author: Toni M.

description:
Sunday we attend the Impressionists and went to the Cafe.

Ordered Bisque which was tasteless mess of kitchen collections; cookie seemed from old flour; chicken sandwich on the lifeless, tasteless side; potato salad which came with the pulled pork was about 2 tablespoons worth also on the tasteless side.
All in all, food for the price was on the insipid level; basically no flavor, no taste, no seasoning to taste, even the coffee mocha tasted more like plain hot chocolate but more on the watery side.

Times before food was very good, but today, unfortunately, food was terrible.
East Bay Resident

This is Bisque by definition but not at the Cafe:

Bisque is a type of rich, thick, creamy soup which has been pureed so that it has an even texture. Traditionally, bisque includes seafood, wine or cognac, and cream, along with a mixture of spices. Bisque is related to consomme, which is another rich soup produced through a long cooking process that concentrates flavors for intensity. As the name suggests, bisque has its origins in France, although the dish is prepared all over the world with a wide variety of ingredients.
author: Nando o.

description: The atmosphere on the cafe patio is great. Really comfortable and climate controlled but you feel like you are outside. The food is over priced and not very good if you are eating from the pre-made sandwiches and salads area. I would only have a coffee or dessert there next time and save my real appetite for a meal at a neighborhood restaurant.
author: Leuwam T.

description: What a beautiful place to sit and enjoy a cup of coffee or a nice organic salad! The prices were reasonable, the scenery beautiful, and the food tasty. Avoid this place during lunch time as the lines are very very long. If they could control the lines, I'd give this place 5 stars.
author: Kristine Y.

description: Way too crowded, lines are huge, the place is loud and the food is way overpriced. Oddly enough, I did enjoy the atmosphere and didn't find that the chaos of the crowds to be too counter to pensivity. I wouldn't go out of my way to come here for a meal or even a coffee, but it's an alright place to stop and reflect on the exhibits.
author: Mahrya Q.

description: Good coffee, but Academy of Sciences has better food in their caffeteria, and you don't have to go through the guard guantlet.
author: J. G.

description: Two stars for the ambiance and the cool sculptures that adorn the garden surrounding the cafe.  These are its only redeeming qualities.  Besides that, everything else is sub-par.  If this cafe weren't in the de Young Museum, where it benefits from a captive audience, this place would not survive.  The food was fair at best and it definitely was not worth its prices.  To make matters worse, the portions are small.  I think I paid something like $10 for an anemically loaded sandwich with no chips and no drink.  Needless to say, I was still hungry even after I had consumed my sandwich.  To make matters worse, I patronized this place on a Saturday during the lunch rush.  The lines were extremely long and there were few tables available.  Try to avoid the crowds if you can.
author: Sophrosyne Y.

description: Simply enjoyed a dessert and coffee after visiting the Birth of Impressionism.  The solarium was nice.  The coffee was perfectly made.  Mostly notable was the warm, friendly, attentive & professional staff.
author: Gen d.

description: Food looks good, food looks fresh, even the plates are nice....BUT, it doesn't taste good. So, just stick to drinking Chardonnay.  (Red wine choice is not good either.)
author: Wakako U.

description: After the King Tut exhibit, my bf and I decided to grab a quick bite at the museum cafe. We weren't expecting much to begin with, but we were pleasantly surprised by the quality of the food. Both the caesar & the tomato salads were fresh, the curry chicken sandwich was delicious, and the boysenberry cheescake was just spectacular! Although the food is great, they are ridiculously overpriced.
author: H J.

description: It's OK as far as musem cafes go.  Actually, it's cliche as far as museum cafes go.  Eating here is like eating at every other museum cafe you've ever been to.  The food is OK and overpriced, like it is at every other museum.  The wait's a little too long.
author: John S.

description: Whoa, this place was packed on the afternoon after TDay, 2009. The clam chowder was quite good, although it may have been a bit too heavy on the large chunks of potato.  The waldorf salad was impressive with fresh figs, pomegranate, endive and a tangerine vinegrette, instead of that yuck mayonnaise dressing.   There was more chicken than lettuce.
author: christian C.

description: Fantastic mac n' cheese. Looks like a small portion - but its not - really! This stuff sticks to the ribs. The tomato soup was good too.
author: Judy L.

description: Had a pretty dry ready made sandwich (ham and cheese) and a white tea/peach drink.  The menu was pretty limited and nothing appeared interesting to me, so I went the pre-made route.  My wife had an ok lamb curry dish, and our daughter had some mac and cheese and fries.  The SFMOMA cafe is several orders of magnitude better.  But, if you're at the De Young, you are sort of limited in where you can grab a bite.
author: geoff c.

description: Most museum restaurants and cafes are very mediocre. There are a few that stand out, such as the cafe at the MOMA in NYC. But, the Cafe at the De Young is just 'so/so'. They try hard with their use of sustainable products and info flyers on the tables about carbon diets, etc. But, the food is very average and overpriced. I think $11-13 is a bit steep for a small chicken caesar salad. And, $2.25 for a bag of chips is just highway robbery. But, if you're at the De Young and can't wait til you hike over to the plethora of restaurants around 9th and Lincoln, then the cafe is just fine. Lots of indoor and outdoor seating. Probably best for a caffeine boost in between exhibits. Save your appetite for a great restaurant outside of Golden Gate Park.
author: Maren P.

description: Had dinner this evening and boy was I surprised!  We ordered off the menu and the food was not only inexpensive at 3 items for just $13.00, but incredibly delicious to boot!  We ordered the Lamb with Couscous & yogurt, crab cake, & prosciutto w/pears.  I didn't have any of the prosciutto, but my wife loved it.  I did, however, have the other two and my mouth was so happy I could cry.  The portions were nicely european sized and just enough to give one a good taste, but not too much.  All together, the 3 items were plenty of food for one and enough to two with lite appetites.  We definitely plan on tucking this place away for future reference!
author: tstms R.

description: After viewing the Post Impressionist Masterpieces exhibit we were craving for a bit to eat and decided to try the cafe inside the museum.  The main dining area was virtually filled to capacity as the covered patio area was closed.  I had eaten here a few years back and remembered it to be pricey and the portions slight.  My memory was right.  I decided to try the Ruben sandwich while my friend had the ravioli.  My sandwich was $12.50 while the ravioli was $13.00.  My sandwich was quite tasty and came with a small side salad of roasted squash and peppers topped with some currants and a couple of mandarin orange segments.  Good, but wished the portions were larger.  My friend's ravioli looked good as it was stuffed with cheese and in a red sauce with a few roasted vegetables.  She complained that it was bland and would have liked a larger portion.  I can understand paying a premium to eat at the museum, just wish the portions were a bit larger.  Next time I come up to the museum will have to try some of the eateries just outside the park before or after.
author: Perry W.

description:
ate here because it was the closest restaurant to yoyo competition that was being held in the park area.
way, way, waaay overpriced. $8 for a hotdog? go to costco.
i had the sloppy joe thing. that wasn't so bad. the potato salad was pretty bad, though--very bland.
author: Kenneth H.

description: Beautiful presentation all around. Good selections for vegetarians and meat eaters alike, as well as beverages including some wine/beer and coffee drinks. I had the risotto of asparagus, sauted wild mushrooms, and lemon parsley gremolata, topped by shards of dry vella jack and a parmesan crisp. wonderful aromas, well picked veggies cooked just right. I have to nick off some of the rating because I felt the risotto wasn't cooked enough, i.e., although the flavors were wonderful, the rice wasn't soft and overall texture not creamy enough. It's an amazing operation the cafe runs in providing ready-made and hot food on the aesthetic level they achieve. Improvements in the service can still be had; more than the basics are already in place. I hope to visit again.
author: Ryan T.

description: The food here was good, not great.  My main beef with it was that the service sucked.  The cafe was packed the day we went and when we finally grabbed a table it had a bunch of dirty dishes on it.  We pushed them to the corner and assumed one of the bussers would take care of it.  Turns out not.  Our food was brought out, we ate, and we left without having it ever taken care of.
author: Katie S.

description: I hate to be a party-pooper but I just don't like the cafe here. With all the millions and millions of dollars they spent on every little part of this museum... which works great in the museum itself... I wonder why the cafe can be so easily improved by changing it into a franchise coffee shop. Sad, no?
author: Andrew W.

description: I went to the museum today, and thought it would be a good idea to go to the cafe to eat before I visited the wonderful Picasso exhibit. To my suprise the burger my father ordered was completely rare, they brought him a new one and it still remained very rare on the inside, it was completly uneatble. I orderd the chicken dish which tasted alright at the time, but a few hours later I began to feel very sick. My advice would be to eat somewhere else before visitng the museum and your day will be alot better then mine was.
author: molly c.

description: The menu has been slightly different each time I have eaten here.  The last time I went I had "The Works" baked potato.  It was pretty tasty except for the  huge broccoli pieces that were completely tasteless.  It was raining the day I went so finding a table was a huge pain, but they were clearing the empty tables quickly.  Perfect for a quick bite after a day of walking.
author: Caroline B.

description: The menu is a little short, but that's common for a museum café. The prices we're typical and you had all the usual museum fare. Soup was good, fruit salad was good, and I spend under $10 on lunch. Not bad.
author: Thomas S.

description: My daughter had the kid's pasta yesterday and came home fine.  About an hour or so later, she got sick.  She was sick all night.  She said the past tasted different from what she was used to, her Nonna's pasta.  If you go, don't get the kid's pasta.
author: amy T.

description: Surprisingly decent for monopolized cafe fare: ham sandwich, potato salad (with bacon), seafood chowder (also with bacon). Not surprisingly overpriced.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Not too bad as far as museum cafes go.  Definitely overpriced.  The decor isn't too bad.  We spent $42.00 for three people for food today.  Sure, free admission to the museum, but we more than paid for it just in food.  We had two Banh Mi sandwiches (with Alaskan Rock Cod, I believe) and the Pasta Romo - which I actually really liked.  The portions don't look very big, but once you mix it up a bit, it just grows and seems neverending.  I was stuffed.
author: Kris L.

description:
pricey.  does that say it all? we ordered a hot dog, fries, fruit salad, and 2 sodas.  total came out to be $21 something.  i guess you can't find cheap food in the park or in a museum.  we were hungry so i guess we don't have much choice.  

the layout of the restaurant/cafe is nice.  the lights that hang above is unique.  very artsy like the rest of the museum.  

food wise... the hot dog was a hot dog, the fries were fries.  nothing special.  everytime i come here, there's always people... like i said, there's no other place in the museum or in the park.  not much of a choice.  i will come back here again because i m always thirsty after walking around in the sun.  But, i m glad that we have a museum like this in the city.  that's what make SF unique.
author: Kapo T.

description: OVERPRICED is the word. The sandwiches here are ok and is big enough to share. If I am starving while browsing at the museum, I would eat here otherwise I'd prefer to go further to get my grub.
author: Topazskye L.

description:
One Minute Review

1. Food tasted: cheeseburger, fries; well cooked, tasty, not greasy, above average presentation for a cafe.
