2. Service: friendly but very slow (30 mins. to bring food out). 
3. Decor: pleasant but open tables were difficult to find; the outer dining area was very sunny on that day but as a result a little too warm.
4. Price: expensive for a cafeteria ($9.50 for a cheeseburger) but understandable given higher quality food and museum setting.
5. Location: easy access to and from museum; nice view of recently renovated California Academy of Sciences.
6. Overall: you must exercise patience when dining here but it is a convenient place to fuel up during your trip to the museum or other attractions in the area.
author: Noueman H.

description:
i tried to take my wife to see the king tut exhibit at the de young museum this past saturday.  last month, we were at the museum, but the king tut exhibit wasn't yet open.  we had arrived there pretty late in the afternoon, and the museum wasn't going to be open for much longer.  we asked the girl ticket counter how much longer the museum would be open for, and she basically told us it wouldn't be worth it for us to buy tickets at this point but that the tower is free and that the museum would be free in a little bit.  i forget if it's free after 4:00 or 4:30 pm, but it's free after some time.  well, we had a great time there that day.  when we came back, well... we were disapointed that the king tut exhibit was sold out, but we walked around some free gallery and then went to each lunch at the cafe before strolling around the numerous, numerous king tut gift shops.

since i loved the food at the academy of sciences moss room cafeteria, i knew to expect high quality, fresh, locally grown, organic, healthy, socially conscious, environmentally friendly food at _this_ museum cafe.  i was right.  the food is great!  sure, it ain't cheap; but it's quality stuff.  for my wife and me, i ordered a sloppy poppy sandwich (a pulled pork sandwich with jack and cheddar with some kind of wild rice salad thingy) and a curry chicken salad.  yeah, the food was very good, very fresh, and came in pretty good portions.  i also got us a cup of decaf coffee for $1.75.  since i was feeling happy that day, i gave the cashier a pretty hefty tip, probably overtipped... but oh well; whatever.  i mean, i know some people say tipping at places where you pay first is only for suckers.  however, i figure that, since they would be bringing the food out to me based upon the number they gave me to place on my table, that i should include a tip.  i went a _little_ overboard, but whatever.

my wife noted that the chicken salad didn't have enough vegetables.  however, i think all the food was very tasty.  i also i like how they have different kinds of ice water: plain, lemon, lime, and cucumber.  i drank mostly cucumber ice water.
author: beno h.

description: For those of you planning a "group" trip to the De Young, don't forget the Cafe also offers "box lunches"!  Our church staff, 16 of us, enjoyed a staff outing to the Impressionist exhibit yesterday and had ordered the box lunches and they are AWESOME!  Huge sandwiches, great selection including an ahi tuna sandwich that got rave reviews -- and we are all still thinking about the yummy white chocolate chip cookies for dessert.  Well worth the price!
author: Cathy J.

description: High quality, reasonably priced, clean, cafeteria style with freshly made plates served by wait staff.
author: L M.

description: I was at the De Young for the King Tut exhibit and decided to visit the cafe after hearing it was one of the best museum cafes.  Boy, they were right.  Don't let the cafeteria-like appearance fool you.  Their food is legit.  They have refrigerated sandwiches and pantry food, but you can also order off a menu, which is where the good stuff's at.  We  had the shredded pork sandwich, the mac and cheese, and the curry chicken salad (which wasn't really a salad, more like a pile of chicken with bits of lettuce).  The food came super fast, and I was very impressed by the presentation.  Someone really put some thought into the dishes.  The pork sandwhich was amazing as well as the mac and cheese.  The curry chicken salad was good but I wanted more greens! If you happen to be in the area, definitely make sure to stop by this cafe as you won't be disappointed.  I didn't give it 5 stars since the food was a bit pricey for what it is.
author: Alex H.

description: Good food, healthy options, airport prices. There are sandwiches, desserts, salads, and soup. I tried the grab & go spicy Asian rice noodle salad with steak slices for $5.00 and the mushroom & barley soup of the day. My boyf had a sandwich, chips, and the bread pudding. The Asian salad was really good...overpriced but good. The soup was sad. There was maybe one mushroom, no barley, and a few cooked tomato pieces. Nothing else but broth, so that was a waste of money. I like that they have free ice water ready to go and you can get it with cucumbers, limes, lemons, or plain. Boyf says the sandwich was okay but not worth the $10. The bread pudding, I have to say, was awesome. It was quality all the way. It comes with this delish sweet cream on top and fruit puree, and some kind of strawberry creamy sauce on the side that reminded me of a strawberry milkshake. So, to sum it up, not a bad place to go if you want something fairly healthy without having to drive somewhere else, but bring money. You'll need it.
author: Sarah S.

description: WOW!  That is all I can say.  This little place is a hidden 'food' mine stuck in the middle of beautiful Golden Gate Park then wedged in the Ohhh so cool de Young museum.  I have dinned there numerous times and it was always over excellent, both the food and service, not to mention the place is clean and I am a 'super clean freak.'  However, we stumbled in there on a Friday night and had this menu that had a choice of 3 items out of 15 for only $15.00.  WT_!  I had mussels, braised short ribs and amazing french fries cut with a knife (who does that anymore).  The wife, had lamb skewered things, more mussels and oysters.  They also offer very affordable QUALITY wine!  Seriously, we had to race home to change our pants because it was so over the top.  Well, actually we just went to the observation deck to check out the best view of SF.  An amazing 'what an experience!'
author: tommy d.

description: When the new De Young first opened, there was a great cafe with fast service and friendly waiters. Now it is noisy and crowded. The waiters are rushed and stressed out. The food is okay, but on two occasions my fries have been delivered cold. Good coffee, though, and it's nice to be able to have access to the cafe without having to pay the admission to the museum.
author: Bethany D.

description: Ordered two salads here for lunch yesterday . . . facts:  I am not a big "salad girl," nor do I particularly care for cafeteria-style set-ups.  These were honestly two of the best salads my friend and I have ever had in our lives . . . enough to make us think about trying that move to vegetarianism again this year.  Quinoa salad and pear salad.  Order these and prepare to die - fresh, full of subtle flavors and perfect textures and served in a lovely garden setting outside in Golden Gate park.  It doesn't get any better than this for lunch.  Service great also.
author: Eleanor S.

description: Grabbed a few bites before checking out de Young's weekly "Friday nights at the de Young" (where the museum opens its doors after hours for a night of music, cocktails, poetry, tours, lectures, and whatever else artsy fartsy types do on a Friday night). The menu offered some potentially good dishes: shredded pork lettuce wraps, pancetta pizzette, fingerling potato frites, etc. Disappointingly, these dishes pretty much fizzled except for the mac 'n cheese offered in the kids' section of the menu. In fact, my husband had to go back to the counter (yes, this is still a cafe, after all) and ordered a couple more. I suppose the kitchen staff got confused for we ended up having double the amount of mac 'n cheese brought to our table. We were dining with some friends and I overheard how great the Neiman Ranch hotdog was, which they ordered for their boys. I guess if you want to have some good eats at this cafe, just order off the kids' menu. Although, the menu is seasonal so there is still hope.
author: April B.

description: missing in action, place always packed?  disjointed service and where's the manager, crepevine should take over .... offering prepackaged foods, bake no goodies ... disappointment the museum is so worthy of so much more, im not talking four stars, just good food served in a timely manner in a clean place!
author: tim y.

description: This was my third time eating at the de Young's cafe - each time it's gotten worse and we think next time, we'll just bring our own picnic to the park.  The service is extremely, painstakingly slow - the first two times it took 30 minutes for our mediocre meal to arrive and this time it took a whopping 40 minutes...ridiculous.   The basic hamburger (both ordered medium) - one came out well-done and the other was nearer to rare.  I ordered a pasta dish that sounded good on the menu but it was bland and soggy - disgusting for $13.  For a top notch museum, the restaurant lacks sorely....stay away unless you have over an hour to burn at the cafe....
author: Vivian C.
